dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TITLE CARD: the early 15th century A scorched battlefield littered with the dead and dying. Hundreds of tangled bodies strewn across the field. Horse them. So thick and twisted they carpet the sodden earth. deformed mass. Bloody, black and brown. A WARRIOR walks the field. Broad shouldered. A cape of fu leather and chain mail. He walks laboured. A body squirms at his feet. He stops. He raises his worn and, as if planting a flag, he thrusts the metal down int dying man’s back. The body arches stiff and then goes lim He continues on in this fashion, casually roaming the des bodies and giving those still moving their silence. Aroun across the field, others pore over the bodies, pilfering valuables or taking the not-fatally wounded hostage. The warrior turns. His scarred face, young but lined. Sad soulful eyes. Despite being a clear victor here, he looks displeased, agitated, dark. This is SIR HENRY ‘HOTSPUR’ PERCY. He continues his macab walk. He stops at the body of a man wheezing his last shallow b into the dirt. With his filthy, bloody boot, Hotspur heav man onto his back and regards him with what looks for a m like pity. He then plunges his sword into the man’s chest Walk. Stab. Walk. Stab. He watches an injured man stand shakily and walk - fall - his feet again and walk. The man trips and keeps moving. Hotspur walks beside him for a few steps. Falling into st watches the limping man’s action, studies him curiously. from a deep gash across his face makes it impossible for see from either eye. Other injuries too.

dialogues.speaker: HOTSPUR
dialogues.text: Where go you, my friend? The man turns to the sound. Scared, he tries to continue. HOTSPUR (CONT’D) You're hobbling in the wrong direction. That wind you feel is blowing from England. Scotland is that way.  The limping man, uncertain, turns and follows the wind. Hotspur turns and walks away. Stab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Royal Court, London. Hotspur, cleaned from the battlefiel walks the hall with his father, the EARL OF NORTHUMBERLAN beside him. Northumberland appears wary. Hotspur strides. They are met by sentries and the Chief Justice SIR WILLIA GASCOIGNE.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: My Lords Percy.

dialogues.speaker: HOTSPUR
dialogues.text: We have come to see the King.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I'm afraid His Majesty is engaged with other concerns. Is he expecting your visit?

dialogues.speaker: HOTSPUR
dialogues.text: I should hope he is. We are but the men who have spilled blood in his name. I should hope that he expects our visit with enthusiasm. William notes Hotspur’s hostility and disappears through antechamber to a room beyond. Hotspur’s agitation is a source of unease for Northumberl an unease which cannot be addressed openly before the sil helmeted sentries standing watch.

dialogues.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
dialogues.text: My son. Be calm. Hotspur stares, boiling, in the direction of the door bey which the King is engaged with his other matters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hotspur and Northumberland sit at one end of a long dinin table. They are quiet. Hotspur’s agitation boils. A door opens. KING HENRY IV hobbles in. Royal courtiers f William, the EARL OF WESTMORLAND, LORD SCROPE OF MASHAM, EARL OF CAMBRIDGE, SIR THOMAS GREY, the EARL OF DORSET am them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My lords, I am most sorry for making you wait. I know you have travelled far and from great travail. The King extends his signet for the lords to kiss. Northumberland does so obligingly, eyes lowered. Hotspur kisses the ring while looking Henry coldly in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY IV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I pray you will know this time of civil unrest consumes me day and night. As the King and his courtiers take their seats, servants food to the table. Others present jugs and bowls of water the men to rinse their hands.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY IV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I understand battle with the rebel Scots was hard fought. Is this true? Hotspur stares. Northumberland fills the awkward space.

dialogues.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
dialogues.text: It was, my liege. We lost some three hundred men. They bow their heads as the King says a Latin blessing.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY IV
dialogues.text: Benedic nos Démine et haec Tia déna quae de Tia largitdte stmus sumptiri. Per Christum Déminum néstrum. Amen.

dialogues.speaker: . ALL
dialogues.text: Amen. The men eat, the King as heartily as his frailty will all Hotspur doesn’t eat. Henry looks to him.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY IV
dialogues.text: And how many prisoners were taken?

dialogues.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
dialogues.text: Some two hundred, my liege.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY IV
dialogues.text: Good Hotspur, you led the charge. Were any prisoners of note taken?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Many.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY IV
dialogues.text: Are they in train?

dialogues.speaker: HOTSPUR
dialogues.text: No. Henry eats, ignoring the insolence.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY IV
dialogues.text: And why is that? Why have they not been brought directly to me as is their designation?

dialogues.speaker: HOTSPUR
dialogues.text: Why will you not pay cousin Mortimer’s ransom?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY IV
dialogues.text: You’1l need to speak up, my boy. I’m an old man. My ears are filled with hair.

dialogues.speaker: HOTSPUR
dialogues.text: Cousin Mortimer is held by the rebels of Wales. Why do you refuse to pay his ransom?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY IV
dialogues.text: I refuse to pay Mortimer’s ransom because I refuse to believe Mortimer a prisoner. I rather believe Mortimer to be a traitor. Henry lets this sit. He eats. Hotspur boils. Moments pass

dialogues.speaker: HENRY IV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your victory over the Scots was a most heroic one, heroic because improbable. Our most recent loss to the Welsh, however, should not have been suffered. Our strength should have had it staved. And I must conclude only that it was suffered with Mortimer’s help, that Mortimer has joined the Welsh rebels, that he has betrayed England and that far from being a prisoner, your cousin is now an enemy of mine and, therefore, of yours.  5. Henry examines his chicken wing. Hotspur stares. The othe try not to be noticed.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY IV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you agree with my précis, good Hotspur?

dialogues.speaker: HOTSPUR
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
dialogues.text: My son.

dialogues.speaker: HOTSPUR
dialogues.text: I believe yours to be the ramblings of a crazy old demon.

dialogues.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
dialogues.text: Harry. Please. Stop this.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY IV
dialogues.text: Let him speak. I wish to hear him.

dialogues.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
dialogues.text: My liege -

dialogues.speaker: HOTSPUR
dialogues.text: Yours are the ramblings of an old man so saturated with malice and mistrust that he no longer knows up from down, who can no longer see beyond the walls of his own monstrous schloss. Henry stops eating. He pays Hotspur his full attention, a inviting Hotspur to continue. Hotspur, emboldened, does s HOTSPUR (CONT’D) My family has served you. My father, my uncle. We aided you in your ascension. And still we fight for you. Cousin Mortimer has fought for you - hard and for many years. And yet while you now slobber over that chicken’s wing, he shivers in a western prison awaiting mutilation at the hands of Welsh witches.

dialogues.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
dialogues.text: My liege, you must forgive my son. He needs rest. We come only to advocate for your help in securing Mortimer’s release.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All that we have done for you we have done for the good of England, but I fear now that we have made a terrible mistake. I fear the battles we have fought have been fought only to indulge your hateful madness. Our lands are now more riven with war than ever before. You have rebellion stewing in all corners. The Scots are not finished. The Welsh have only just begun. And for what? Why do you think this might be, old man? Who do you imagine might be to blame for this? All are stunned silent. Henry watches Hotspur strangely a impassively for a protracted moment.

dialogues.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
dialogues.text: My liege...

dialogues.speaker: HENRY IV
dialogues.text: They say chickens can’t fly, but I’ve seen one eke enough wing flap to clear a fence. And then it’s free!... But then so too are the foxes. Henry continues his dull stare at Hotspur. Hotspur boils, Henry’s gleeful crypticism is intimidating.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY IV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You are right, young Percy. I owe you much. I owe your family still more. You have fought nobly for me. You carry wounds fresh for me to see. And your grievances too - they have been heard. But if the Scottish traitors you have taken prisoner are not brought to me as speedily as they might travel, I will hang you by your fucking neck. Henry watches him another moment.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY IV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Has this been heard, Percy? Hotspur fumes. He heaves his chair from the table and str the door. Northumberland rises meekly and bows. Scrope looks to him, catching his eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please forgive us, Your Majesty. They scurry after Hotspur. Henry watches them leave. The courtiers remain silent, unable to read the King’s dispos

dialogues.speaker: HENRY IV
dialogues.text: What a venomous boy. He’ll betray me now. I’m sure of it. Henry returns his attention to his chicken wing.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY IV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But if only he were my son.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PRINCE ‘HAL‘ HENRY (25) lies face down and naked on a bed a spartan single-room apartment. He’s sprawled and snorin Daylight punches through the window. Sounds of people and animals from the street below. The sound of keys in the door. It opens. An unkempt SIR J FALSTAFF (45) and BEALE (26) enter. Falstaff’s arm bleeds Falstaff shuts the door behind him loudly. Hal wakes with start.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: What is this?

dialogues.speaker: BEALE
dialogues.text: Falstaff has injured his self.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: How did you get in?

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: The door was ajar.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: It wasn’t.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: It was. It was ajar.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: It was not ajar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How else might I gain entry? Are you accusing me of having cut myself a secret key?

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: BEALE
dialogues.text: Falstaff has injured his self, Hal.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Why have you come here? What happened to you? Hal’s head is throbbing. Beale rifles through Hal’s stuff

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: I think it best a man of your standing not be burdened with those particulars. I think it best the circumstances in which the injury was accrued be left entirely mysterious. Beale has found a bottle of liquor.

dialogues.speaker: BEALE
dialogues.text: (to Hal) Will you perform the small repairs?

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: Your Highness. This task requires expertise. Should you not assist, I fear our friendship may come to a foul end right here on your floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal stirs honey in a pot. Beale pours wine over the gash Falstaff’s arm.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: There’s a fresh coin in this for you.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: I don’t want your coin. I will require your undiminished loyalty and devotion from here til Megiddo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have that already. You’re a soft negotiator. Hal puts the honey pot down and goes to the fireplace. He an iron rod from the fire. Beale trickles more booze.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're wasting good wine.

dialogues.speaker: BEALE
dialogues.text: I’m keeping it clean. Hal sits beside Falstaff. He wipes the wound with a strip linen. He then presses the red hot poker right onto it. F screams a scream that quickly turns to maniacal laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal, Falstaff and Beale walk the street in a mangy part o London. Butchers’ stalls, garbage and mud. Fires and smok Dogs, pigs and filthy kids. Two men in clean cloaks step out of a dark doorway and fo Another two men appear from an alley and step in front of their mouths and noses covered by handkerchiefs.

dialogues.speaker: CLOAKED MAN
dialogues.text: Prince Henry. Falstaff and Beale are immediately on edge. They reach discreetly inside their coats for concealed weapons.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: CLOAKED MAN
dialogues.text: We come from the royal court. We wish to speak with you privately.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: CLOAKED MAN
dialogues.text: Please, sire. Privately.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: Privately in the middle of Eastcheap? Shall I make a quick up and down to request a mass covering of ears?  10.

dialogues.speaker: CLOAKED MAN
dialogues.text: (ignoring Falstaff) Please, sire. Hal registers the look of earnest intent on the cloaked m face. He leads him away into a darkened alcove.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: What is this?

dialogues.speaker: CLOAKED MAN
dialogues.text: Your father, His Majesty King - Hal pulls the kerchief from the man’s face, forcing him t breathe the fetid air. CLOAKED MAN (CONT’D) Your father, His Majesty King Henry, is ill. He requests your presence. Hal pauses momentarily, processing this mention of his fa

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: CLOAKED MAN
dialogues.text: Your presence has been requested.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: I suggest you return to the palace directly and tell him his request was wholly ignored.

dialogues.speaker: CLOAKED MAN
dialogues.text: I have been instructed to deliver the request with great urgency.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Then you might tell him your urgency was also wholly ignored. Hal steps past the man, leading Falstaff and Beale away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dingy tavern. Falstaff sits with others, among them Bea a drunk Hal.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: Remember. Remember that as we speak there are two Popes. Two! One in Rome. One in France. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: They both claim to be the Lord’s voice here on earth. They can not both be. Why would a good Lord allow his kingdom to be so puzzled? He wouldn't, is that question's answer.

dialogues.speaker: DRINKER
dialogues.text: Which then is the true Pope?

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: I say not one or the other. I say the very fact of their quarrel makes them both snakes. And so, if our holy Roman fathers can not convey to us a true voice of authority, why should we assume that those snakes beneath them speak with any authority? The whole house is writhing with snakes -

dialogues.speaker: DRINKER
dialogues.text: Stop this now.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: Why now?

dialogues.speaker: DRINKER
dialogues.text: I says stop.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: Are you afraid Thomas might come for you in the night? Don’t be afraid of my ideas. They’re only ideas.

dialogues.speaker: DRINKER
dialogues.text: You sit before me now and tell me you no believe in the power of the one true God.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: I do not. I do believe in the one true God. How dare you suggest otherwise. I do not believe that our Archbishop of Canterbury speaks for him. I would say our Archbishop Thomas Arundel only claims to speak for him.

dialogues.speaker: DRINKER
dialogues.text: To what end?  12.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: Clearly to his own damned end.

dialogues.speaker: DRINKER
dialogues.text: You best bite your tongue in the company you keep. You’1ll have yourself necked.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: (to Hal) You would have me necked? Hal smiles.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to the drinker) I would say your devotion to the Archbishop - if it is devotion and not a slickly ruse to warm the mood of this company I keep - I would say it has me a more true believer in the one God than you.

dialogues.speaker: DRINKER
dialogues.text: Bite your tongue or I will neck you myself.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: Bite my tongue? Why on this earth would I bite my own tongue?

dialogues.speaker: DRINKER
dialogues.text: Your word in this air is a poison.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: Oh. My voice riles you. Maybe then better you should bite your own ears off. (starts laughing at the thought of it) Bite your own ears off! And maybe after you should kick yourself in your own balls! The drinker stands as if to confront Falstaff. Hal laughs From across the room, the tavern’s hostess HOOPER yells -

dialogues.speaker: HOOPER
dialogues.text: Stop now. Falstaff meanwhile is attempting to bite his own ears off And then as the drinker takes a step closer, Falstaff spr up and pins him against a wall, a dagger to his throat.  13.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: Now now. Settle, my petal. You have a little brutish feeling in your belly. I see there be only one course to straighten this dispute... (beat, cold stare) You and I will cockfight... (releases the drinker, his tone lightens instantly) Hal, my knee is queer. You must be my cock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A space has been cleared on the floor to stage the cockfi The ‘cocks’ are Hal and the drinker, crouched on haunches facing off. Beale stands behind Hal holding a horizontal sword six inches over his head. Another man stands behind drinker, holding a stick six inches over his.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: Rules are plain. You topple over, you lose. You rise your head to the level, you lose. Those are the rules. Un, deux, trois. The fight is on. Hal and the drinker waddle towards each other, swiping and grabbing. They tussle, retreat. Tussle retreat. Onlookers yelp support. And then Hal grabs the drinker by his knee and topples him over. Onlookers howl. Falstaff raises his arms in the air.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The Lord hath spoken! Hal lies on his back, laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal is drunk. He kisses a young woman on the bed. They la

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Your Highness. Hal stops laughing. WOMAN (CONT’D) Your Highness. Hal covers her mouth. He is suddenly dark and distant.  14.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Stop. She is taken by surprise, intimidated.

dialogues.speaker: HAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Stop. Hal takes his hand away. She seems uneasy. He kisses her. woman has gone quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal snoring. The woman sleeps beside him. Then the sound key in the door - Falstaff enters. He opens the curtain, stirring the woman unforced chivalry, he coaxes her from bed. Hal doesn’t st

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: My lady. It’s time to leave. He gathers her clothes. She wakes groggily.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That’s good, my dear. Jump up. The day has begun.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: Shhh. The day has begun. Look. Out there. It’s well underway. You might miss it. Disoriented, the woman lifts herself. Falstaff holds her

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's the spirit. Lift your arms. She lifts her arms. Falstaff pulls the shirt down over he

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m sorry to interrupt your slumber. He ushers her out of the room and closes the door behind places a cup of ale beside Hal and sits.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: What are you doing? Hal speaks muffled, groggy, face smudged into the pillow.  15.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: Can you hear me? Hal grunts.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You must get that door fixed.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: Visit with your father.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Go away.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: If your father is indeed enough gravely ill to request your presence, then you must visit with him - it should be better to regret having done so than it would to have not. No matter your feelings for him. If your father is ill, you must visit with him. And - let me add - I say it not out of concern for our king’s well being, more for fear of the drunken soak to which you be likely to succumb should you fail to heed his call and he were to die without you having squared your ledger... I fear it would be soak enough to put even me to shame. Hal stares at Falstaff, lucid and penetrating, with his o not smudged into the pillow. Falstaff watches Hal a momen

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do it. If nothing else I ever suggest. Falstaff rises and exits. Hal percolates Falstaff's advic

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal at the palace gates. Without exchange with the guards granted entry. All watch him with cold interest if not di  16.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal walks the hall under escort. As he approaches the antechamber he crosses paths with Grey and Cambridge on t way into the great hall. Grey eyes him with contempt. Cambridge looks at him cautiously, searching. William approaches Hal with something more like compassio genuflects subtly.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: My lord. Your father expects you.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: He shouldn’t. William observes Hal’s state of dishevelment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: King Henry is in his chair, visibly weak, presiding over sitting of parliament. The full court plus THE ARCHBISHOP CANTERBURY and clerical attendants are there. THOMAS OF LANCASTER, the King’s 18 year-old son, Hal’s yo brother, is there too. The Archbishop is addressing the king. He’s bumptious, bu nervous, and has a lisp.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHBISHOP
dialogues.text: Never. Never would I dare doubt Your Majesty’s piety, however I would remind you of the service we -

dialogues.speaker: HENRY IV
dialogues.text: Archbishop, I would have thought our lord above would want us all to share in his bounty.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHBISHOP
dialogues.text: My liege, while I see the strain your treasury is under, I can not help but wonder if the canker of Lollardy be somehow at the root of this suggestion, that I - or rather the church - be burdened with a tax to relieve problems that are not of the church's making.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Your Highness.  17. The King looks up. Others turn also as Hal steps into the

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Henry, Prince of Wales.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY IV
dialogues.text: My son. Come to me. The Archbishop appears put out. He regards Hal with deris Hal crosses the room. He bows before his father, taking i his frailty. Henry takes in his son’s slovenliness.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY IV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Come closer. Hal takes a step closer. Henry watches him a moment.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY IV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I feel my life is nearing its natural end and yet still even I must appear of ruder health than you. Hal doesn’t respond. He continues looking his father in t

dialogues.speaker: HENRY IV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The time has come for me to consider the issue of my succession. You will not be king. Hal remains fixed. A barely concealed smirk on the face o

dialogues.speaker: HENRY IV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: While you are my eldest son, for reasons that must be evident to you, that are on display for all here to see and smell, you will not inherit this crown.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Nor have I sought it.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY IV
dialogues.text: That privilege and responsibility will instead fall to your brother Thomas. Thomas straightens, postures regally. It doesn’t suit him  18.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY IV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: As you may be aware - to whatever degree you are aware of the world outside your own - I will assume you are aware that the kingdom is at war with itself. Matters as grave as these require leadership committed to their resolution and you - of this I am sure - you can not provide that commitment. Thomas, however, can. He is soft, but he is eager and he will lead my army against the newly treasonous Percy Hotspur. Hal looks at Thomas who has trouble meeting Hal’s eyes.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY IV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I will assume this news comes to you as neither surprise nor disappointment. I do however see it as my duty as King and as father to say it to you directly. Hal walks to Thomas. Thomas raises his head, holds Hal’s eyes.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: How do you feel, brother?

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: Strong.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: When do you fight?

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: I set off tomorrow. We fight by week’s end.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: You need not fight. These feuds need not be yours. Hal takes Thomas’s face in his hand. Thomas leans his hea away and tries to stare at Hal. He is young and afraid.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY IV
dialogues.text: I have said what you were summonsed to hear. Leave us now. Hal turns to his father, one last cold look, then leaves.  19.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slow-motion: Falstaff is drunk, dancing in women’s clothi owning the room with his sweaty heft. Other drinkers laug Hal sits in the corner, oblivious and darkly contemplativ

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A foggy field. Men in armour, horses, an air of trepidati Thomas is helped into his breastplate by an AMROURER. He’ nervous. He raises his arm as a strap is tightened. A CAP waits nearby.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: (pained) Is it not too tight?

dialogues.speaker: ARMOURER
dialogues.text: It has been made to the measurements I was given, sire.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: May be you were given the wrong ones. It feels tight. I can barely turn.

dialogues.speaker: ARMOURER
dialogues.text: It is to be worn tight, sire. Thomas steps away like he’s trying on new shoes. He seems awkward in his heavy suit, overwhelmed by it. He walks am men nearby. He smiles wanly. The men regard him with uncertainty. THOMAS’S CAPTAIN My lord, we must meet with your marshals. As the sun rises, the day will unfold. We must complete our preparations.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas enters the circle of seated men awaiting him. They their heads, but clearly doubt his skill and experience a worry about their own fate as a consequence.  20.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: Lord Dorset, are your men ready for the day?

dialogues.speaker: DORSET
dialogues.text: They are, sire.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: Very good. (awkward beat) Tell me of your preparations. - and then a commotion from beyond the tents. Hal approaches slowly on horseback. A lone muscular figur A hush descends. To most here, Hal is an almost mythical the renegade son of their tyrannical king. He dismounts. He walks to Thomas. The crowd parts for him looks sharp, determined, steely.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why are you here?

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: I will not allow this havoc to transpire. I have come to see it stopped.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: This is my battle. You have no place here.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: If I have my way there will be no battle. Hal turns to a HERALD nearby.

dialogues.speaker: HAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You. Come here.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: You have no place here.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: (to herald) Go to the rebel camp and deliver this message to Percy Hotspur. Tell him that Prince Henry challenges him to settle today’s score man on man. He and I. We fight in our armies’ places.  21.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: I do not need you to fight my battles.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: This battle is not yours. The herald hasn't moved, confused. Hal steps towards him.

dialogues.speaker: HAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Why have you not moved? Go! The herald scurries away. Dorset rises from the circle.

dialogues.speaker: DORSET
dialogues.text: Who do you think you are?

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: I am nobody to you. As you are nobody to me. As Hal walks away, he watches the herald’s horse gallop a the field toward the rebel camp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hotspur stands. Northumberland sits. Scrope is there, hav defected from the King’s inner circle.

dialogues.speaker: HOTSPUR
dialogues.text: I will fight him. I will defeat him.

dialogues.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
dialogues.text: That you surely would, my son.

dialogues.speaker: HOTSPUR
dialogues.text: I will defeat him and we can leave this field whole and victorious.

dialogues.speaker: SCROPE
dialogues.text: That thrill of victory you so foresee would be short lived, for there is little chance that the King Henry would allow us walk free from this field. He would have us forever marked as traitors and we would spend the rest of our days awaiting his recrimination.

dialogues.speaker: HOTSPUR
dialogues.text: The offer has been made.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Prince Henry speaks not for his father. Of this I am certain. You have started something, we have started something much larger here, and we must see it properly concluded.

dialogues.speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
dialogues.text: You're eager to fight, my son. And you will. And we shall fight alongside you. We will burn them. We will burn Henry’s reign to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal is fitting himself with armour. He does so solemnly a meticulously. These may be his last moments alive. Thomas approaches him, furious.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: It is unconscionable that you should seek to commandeer this moment of mine. This moment belongs to me.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: This is not a battle you should be compelled to fight. These troubles are not of your making.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: This is not for you to decide! This is not your place!

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: You do not know war, Thomas.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: I do know war.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: You do not. You may have skirted its perimeter, but you have not been inside it such as that which brews here on this field. And this here is not a place any sane or good man should aspire to know. Hal looks at Thomas, hoping he can see his sincere concer  23.

dialogues.speaker: HAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You have been recruited to our father’s madness, to wars that need not be fought. When I turned my back on him, on my birthright, I was turning my back on this field. These men are not our enemies, but our father has made them thus.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: Why then are you here? You so disapprove of our cause, and yet still you find it necessary to upstage me?

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: I do this not to steal your thunder, brother. I do it to save your life.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: These are not your decisions to make! Westmorland approaches. John turns, agitated.

dialogues.speaker: WESTMORLAND
dialogues.text: Pardon me, my lords.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: WESTMORLAND
dialogues.text: Our herald is returned from the rebel camp. They have refused Prince Henry's offer. Thomas is stunned silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A line of two thousand men and horses - a battle-ready ar across the field, the thin line of Hotspur’s force is vis Thomas strides to Dorset and other officers. All is quiet

dialogues.speaker: DORSET
dialogues.text: You should address the men, my lord - as is customary.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: Of course.  24. Thomas looks around at the mass of men before him. They w him. He clears his throat.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Men. This day shall be a glorious one. It shall be a day that will live on in our memories for many years to come. Beat. Thomas looks nervously at the men staring back him, cold, distrustful. His pause is awkward, long. He continu weakly.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Battles such as this one are the pillars upon which a man’s life is built. Thomas stops. A murmuring from the men. Dorset leans in close.

dialogues.speaker: DORSET
dialogues.text: You must speak up, sire. The men are having difficulty hearing you. Thomas is rattled, embarrassed. He steels himself and the loudly, yelling uncomfortably -

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: I know that many of you doubt me. I know many of you think me unworthy of your respect. But I promise you that today, from this moment, I will do everything in my power to make myself worthy of your respect. Awkward silence. The men wait for more. None comes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rebel preparations. Hotspur is now in formidable knight’s armour, elaborate and fearsome. He seems troubled. He don his helmet and mounts his horse, also decked in intimidat armour. Together they look powerfully murderous. Hotspur looks around the camp a moment, breathing deep be his visor. He then spurs his horse hard and gallops away across the field towards the English army. Startled attendants call after him.  25.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thomas stands weak before his men.

dialogues.speaker: OFFICER
dialogues.text: Loke! There! All turn to see Hotspur’s lone, sharp approach across the Hotspur rides steadily towards Thomas’s army. As he nears slows, then stops close to the line. He removes his helme

dialogues.speaker: HOTSPUR
dialogues.text: Where is Henry? I have come to fight him, in our armies’ stead. Thomas steps forward, distressed and angry.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: No. His offer was refused. We are ready.

dialogues.speaker: HOTSPUR
dialogues.text: The offer has been reconsidered. I will fight Henry. The outcome of that fight shall stand for the larger battle forestalled. It will be done. Hotspur dismounts his horse.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: I said no. It will not be done. Hotspur walks closer.

dialogues.speaker: HOTSPUR
dialogues.text: Why is the little dog barking? Where be the big dog? Hal steps forward, helmet under his arm, sword by his sid

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: It will be done.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: If this here might prevent the death of countless of your men then you should wish it be done. You should wish it be done!  26. Thomas can feel the heavy stare of men who would rather n die, many of whom are themselves unsure of this battle’s Hal watches him a moment, then steps further towards Hots

dialogues.speaker: HOTSPUR
dialogues.text: And here I am with the whoring fool.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: This fight need not be had, Percy. My father will soon be dead, and your grievances will die with him.

dialogues.speaker: HOTSPUR
dialogues.text: Don’t be afraid of our small contest, little Hal. I promise to finish it quickly. Hotspur dons his helmet. Hal watches him. Hal dons his own helmet. He stands firm, raises his sword Hotspur advances, calmly. Hal circles him. HOTSPUR (CONT’D) Your father is plague to England. Hal charges forward, swinging his sword. Hotspur blocks and deflects him easily. Hal stumbles. Hotspur stands calm and cocksure as Hal regathers. HOTSPUR (CONT’D) Come for me, big dog. Hal attacks again, this time steadier, more sure-footed. They trade blows. Hotspur is a powerful and battle-fit wa Hal seems more troubled by the contest, struggling to kee feet and trade blows. They fight, separate and circle each other. Despite his ascendency, Hotspur seems surprised by the fi puts up. He expected the win to be easier. He concentrate Northumberland and Scrope have arrived on horseback from rebel camp. They watch the fight. Another vicious exchange. The men break. They watch each other, catching breath. They circle one another.  21 27. HOTSPUR (CONT’D) Come for me again, dog. Hal raises his sword and stands firm and waits. Hotspur f coldly on him, then charges. The exchange is brutal. Hal his sword. He stands vulnerable. He pulls his dagger from scabbard. Hotspur laughs from behind his visor, then charges again. Hal ducks, spins. Hotspur trips and falls. Hal wheels aro thrusts his dagger straight through Hotspur’s throat. Hotspur is killed. Hal stands over him, heaving for breat The massed English army bearing witness stand silent, shocked, relieved, confused - certainly they didn’t want die, but many felt a greater allegiance to Hotspur than t did the family they were to fight for today. Hal pulls off his helmet. He tosses it on the dirt. He be lifts Hotspur’s helmet off. He contemplates Hotspur’s lif face. He seems saddened by it. Hal carries Hotspur’s helmet over to Thomas. All watch, silent. He drops the helmet at Thomas’s feet.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Some day this will be your head, dropped at the feet of a man who might otherwise have been your brother. Walk away from this field.

dialogues.speaker: THOMAS
dialogues.text: After you have stolen its prized scalp? This is what shall be spoken of tomorrow. This field was mine, it was to mark my dominion. Instead now it marks only this head. This fucking head. Thomas kicks Hotspur’s helmet like a football and walks a through the crowd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Falstaff is asleep in bed snoring. A knock at the door. T opens - it’s hostess Hooper.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: Go away.  22 23 28.

dialogues.speaker: HOOPER
dialogues.text: You might wish to see to your otherwise well appointed friend. He seems to have taken a pitiful turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Falstaff steps into the dark, quiet street to find Beale to rouse Hal who lies drunk and sick against a wall.

dialogues.speaker: BEALE
dialogues.text: Hal's up-chucked again. Falstaff crouches before Hal. Beale steps away.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: Hello, friend. What’s this foul mess you’ve chosen to lie in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tavern has emptied. Hal sits against a wall with a si bucket. Falstaff sits beside him, staring ahead.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: Battle is ugly, brother. Many times have I seen men in your state. I’ve been in it many times over myself. For all our rejoice of courage and valour, nothing stains the soul more indelibly than killing. Never have I felt more vile than standing victorious on a battlefield... The thrill of victory fades quickly. What lingers long after is always ugly. Nothingness... Ugly. Falstaff sits remembering war. He shudders, shakes it off

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Never again, I say.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Stop. Stop talking, old man. Falstaff smiles and pats Hal on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: I will never stop talking, Hal. Falstaff stands and heads for the stairs.  29.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal is asleep on the floor. A gloved hand shakes his shou

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: My lord. Hal wakes. William stands over him, accompanied by a guar

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: What business?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: It is a matter of great urgency.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: You should hurry along then.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Please, my lord. Hal sits up. It’s a struggle. His head is throbbing.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your father, my lord. He is gravely ill.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: That hook has lost its worm. Hal massages his temples. William addresses his guard.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Wait for me outside. The guard exits. William sits on a bench beside Hal.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: England needs a king.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: England may do better without one.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: No doubt your father has brought much trouble to this kingdom, but I fear the chaos that might erupt in his absence. England needs a king and I suspect those sentiments of yours that had you resile from him might be precisely those the governance of this land needs... You must be king.  30.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Why do you say this to me? Speak to Thomas. Is he not to be your new king?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I'm afraid that is not possible, my lord. William pauses. Hal looks at him, suddenly concerned.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your brother was killed in Wales not a week gone by... After your defeat of Lord Percy, young Thomas pressed on to the western fields. This is where he met his end. The news rocks Hal.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It is said he gave valiant account of himself. Hal stands and heads for the door. William watches Hal’s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal’s booming voice echoes off the stone walls of the pal

dialogues.speaker: HAL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Where are you!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Attendants hard at work in the smoky, bustling kitchen lo up at the noise.

dialogues.speaker: HAL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Where are you!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Palace attendants moving furniture in the otherwise empty hall are also startled by the noise.

dialogues.speaker: HAL, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Where is he?!  31.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal strides into his father’s office adjacent to his bedc

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Where is he? Where is the monster? In the office, Grey and others loiter. Grey turns to Hal.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: Tis a grave day, my lord. Hal swings him to the wall.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Is it? Truly? The vultures show the way to the carcass. Hal releases him and bursts through the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal charges in. Cambridge, Dorset, Westmorland and others quietly. The LORD CHAMBERLAIN is there. The Archbishop si beside the bed.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Move. Leave him.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHBISHOP
dialogues.text: The King needs rest.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Soon he will have it. The King lies prone in bed, breathing shallow, face conto

dialogues.speaker: ARCHBISHOP
dialogues.text: He’s dying.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Leave then. It’s too late for you.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHBISHOP
dialogues.text: I give him comfort -

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: (yelling furiously) Get away! The Archbishop backs away, scurries for the door.  32. Hal grabs the sheets from the bed and pulls them off. He over his dying father, shrivelled and exposed on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: HAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You deserve no comfort. The King struggles for breath, wracked with fear. He is c

dialogues.speaker: HAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you feel the cold? Hal waits for some kind of response. Henry is distraught.

dialogues.speaker: HAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (yells) Speak! Do you feel this cold? The King stares into some middle distance, broken and chi

dialogues.speaker: HAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Speak. Hal starts crying now. And then his anger rises again.

dialogues.speaker: HAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Speak, wretch. Speak to me. Courtiers sit quietly, cautious. The King whimpers.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY IV
dialogues.text: (barely intelligible) You must be king, my son. Please. I love you. Hal takes this in. His tears run harder. The King wheezes

dialogues.speaker: HENRY IV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know not what I have done. He continues to wheeze as he fades. Hal looks to the crow sitting on a beside table. He stares at it. Others in the room wait uncomfortably, staring at Hal's b Hal stands. He turns. All stoop apprehensively to a knee.

dialogues.speaker: ALL
dialogues.text: My liege. Hal stands before them.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Look at me.  33. The men look up. He looks them all square. He has hardene

dialogues.speaker: HAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He will be dead by morning. No one breathes. Hal watches them - his world shifting.

dialogues.speaker: HAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know not what will become of you. (beat) And so I offer you now the most blessed reprieve and the most dreadful misery - one and same - that you shall suffer the indignity of serving me, the wayward son you so revile. Hal stares them down.

dialogues.speaker: HAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But know now that you will be watched over by an altogether different king. Pause. The men genuflect again.

dialogues.speaker: HAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Before you falsely honour your new king, you might with fondness farewell your old. Hal catches sight of William, newly arrived.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: William and the Lord Chamberlain with three guards in the street outside Hal’s apartment. William surveys the stree then heads inside it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A key in the door. It swings open. The Lord Chamberlain, and two guards enter to find Falstaff startled awake and disoriented in Hal’s bed.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: What is this?  34.

dialogues.speaker: LORD CHAMBERLAIN
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: I am I. Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: LORD CHAMBERLAIN
dialogues.text: What is your purpose here?

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: I think you just woke me up from it, didn’t you?

dialogues.speaker: LORD CHAMBERLAIN
dialogues.text: Rise from that bed. At once.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: Who are you? Where is Hal?

dialogues.speaker: LORD CHAMBERLAIN
dialogues.text: These lodgings and their contents are the property of the King of England. You are trespassing and I order you to vacate at once. Falstaff is momentarily taken aback. He scoffs.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: What King of England? INT. KING’S BEDCHAMBER / ROYAL COURT - DAY Dressers fit Hal in ceremonial robes. William sits watchi Lord Chamberlain is there too, at attention.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Are you comfortable? Hal adjusts his garments. He isn’t comfortable.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You need only follow the Archbishop's lead. A coronation is one such event at which the King need be little more than present. And awake, I suppose. (beat) Many hours might this day consume but, like any other, it will end. You are an honourable man. You will not be alone in your endeavours. I can assure you of this. You shall have me beside you at every turn.  35.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal walks barefoot in ceremonial procession through a cro of noble onlookers. William, Dorset and Westmorland are w him. The Archbishop leads. Hal seems vulnerable. The crow watches with quiet reserve. He may have inherited the kingdom, but it feels today as though the kingdom owns hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The abbey is huge and full of peers and nobility, watchin Hal on all fours on the chancel, disrobed, wearing only breeches. The Archbishop stands over him, massaging oils his arms, back and shoulders. Hal seems vulnerable, submitting to the arcane, unsettling, almost sexual cerem Bishops bear witness. The crowd watches in silence. LATER: Hal, clothed in full regal attire, sits on a thron the altar. The Archbishop addresses the large crowd.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHBISHOP
dialogues.text: Will ye, sirs, at this time give your wills and assents to this consecration whereunto the people shall say with a great voice, yea, yea, yea, so be it, King Henry, King Henry, King Henry!

dialogues.speaker: CROWD
dialogues.text: King Henry! King Henry! King Henry! The crown of Saint Edward is placed upon Hal’s head. In procession, he is kissed by each of the bishops as he sta out at his inscrutable subjects.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal stands at a huge banquet table, flanked by William, t of York, Dorset, Westmorland, Grey and Cambridge. A few s from Hal sits the Archbishop. In all, forty or more. Duke duchesses. Men of church, war and politics - and, beside these men, women sit watching the new king carefully. Among them is QUEEN PHILIPPA, Hal’s 21 year-old sister, w in marriage - is now Queen of Denmark, Norway and Sweden. sits beside her husband, ERIC OF POMERANIA. Laid out on a side-table near Hal is a great pile of gift Servants remove plates from the table. A meal has been ea  36. The Lord Chamberlain presents one of the gifts to Hal.

dialogues.speaker: LORD CHAMBERLAIN
dialogues.text: From Wenceslaus, King of Bohemia. Hal opens the box and pulls out an ornate vase. He inspec LORD CHAMBERLAIN (CONT’D) (reading from a card) ‘I, King Wenceslaus of Bohemia, present this gift to King Henry of England. To long and good health.’

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Beautiful. Hal looks to Philippa. He walks round the table to her.

dialogues.speaker: HAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: As I’m sure you all know, my young sister Philippa has joined us here today. Queen of Denmark! Hal stands behind her. He lovingly holds her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: HAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I am thankful that she and her husband, the good King Eric, have travelled all this way to wish me well. To wish England well. (to Eric) How stands she, Eric? As queen? I hope nobly.

dialogues.speaker: ERIC
dialogues.text: Well she stands, Your Majesty.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: I'm happy to hear it. I wish for you take this vase, my dear. Let its beauty stand for your beauty which stands in turn for England's beauty. Hal puts the vase on the table before Philippa and kisses cheek. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIPPA
dialogues.text: I thank you, my liege. Hal returns to his seat.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: The next surprise, Lord Chamberlain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From Zsigmond, King of Hungary. (reading card) ‘May your reign be peaceful and your kingdom eternally prosperous.’ 37. Another box. Hal opens it. Inside is a quill and ink pot. inspects it.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: A quill. A nice one. (to William) I feel you should have this gift, Chief Justice, for the signing of royal decree. Let it represent England’s lawfulness.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Thank you, my liege. All at the table enjoy this display of largesse from Hal. are smiling, awaiting the next surprise.

dialogues.speaker: LORD CHAMBERLAIN
dialogues.text: His sincerity, the Doge, and the republic of Venice, present this gift in your honour, my liege. Hal inspects the box, trying to figure out how it opens. LORD CHAMBERLAIN (CONT’D) (reading the gift letter) It says it is a bird from Constantinople.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: A bird! A dead one I should suppose if it has travelled here from Constantinople by Venezia in this box. Laughter at the table. Hal manages to open the box. a small, intricately crafted metal bird. Hal studies it.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: If I may, my liege. Inside is Hal hands the bird to William. William inspects its under and twists a dial there. He places the bird down on the t upon which it flaps its wings like the wind-up toy it is.  38. All at the table gasp, enthralled, horrified, watching th bird twist and flap. They’ve never seen anything like it.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Unnatural mechanics from the edge of Christendom. Hal watches the bird with fascination as it comes to a st He picks it up, turns it over, inspects its underside.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: A wonder... Well, this belongs to my old friend, Lord Cambridge. Hal walks around the table to Cambridge’s seat. He puts t on the table before him and clasps him by the shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: HAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Of all at this table, none have I known longer than I have you. I have indeed known you longer than I have my own young sister. Hal smiles at Philippa. She smiles back carefully. Hal returns his attention to Cambridge.

dialogues.speaker: HAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We were raised together. We played games together. We have fought in battle together. You have been like an older brother to me. And so, in honour of this, I think it only fitting that you, my good Lord Cambridge, should have this magical bird from Constantinople. Let’s hope its magic isn’t black and unholy! Constantinople indeed. Hal kisses Cambridge’s temple as all laugh and applaud. H returns to his seat as Cambridge inspects his new toy.

dialogues.speaker: HAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: More!

dialogues.speaker: LORD CHAMBERLAIN
dialogues.text: From Charles, King of France. The Lord Chamberlain inspects the card. LORD CHAMBERLAIN (CONT’D) Pardon me. Not from the King. It’s from the Prince, his son. The Dauphin.  39. The Lord Chamberlain turns the card over. LORD CHAMBERLAIN (CONT’D) No message.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: No message from the Dauphin? Hal puts the small chest on the table before him. He open and freezes, staring into the box. All wait in anticipation. They sense something wrong. Hal reaches into the box and pulls out an old-style tenni

dialogues.speaker: HAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A ball. Silence. This is clearly an insult to the new king.

dialogues.speaker: HAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There is no accompanying message?

dialogues.speaker: LORD CHAMBERLAIN
dialogues.text: No, my liege. Hal continues looking at the ball. He closes the chest.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: I shall keep this gift. This one is sent for me. He examines the ball, turns it in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: HAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: For the boy that once I was. Hal steps back from the table and throws the ball hard ag the stone wall. It echoes loud and bounces back to him.

dialogues.speaker: HAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The Prince and I might play a set one day. (to Cambridge) You shouldn’t mind, Lord Cambridge, if I found myself a new play friend, would you? For jeu de paume? Muted laughter. Cambridge smiles politely. The women - Ha sister, Philippa, especially - watch Hal closely.  40.

dialogues.speaker: HAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Lord Chamberlain. Next. Make this one a good one, please. We hold on Hal as the Lord Chamberlain sorts uncomfortabl through the remaining gifts.

dialogues.speaker: LORD CHAMBERLAIN
dialogues.text: From The King of Denmark, Eric of Pomerania -

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: (flat) Ah, good Eric. I was hoping yours might be next. As the Lord Chamberlain reads the card, Hal becomes dista

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal sits at the King’s desk, examining a mess of papers. William sits, unsettled, holding the Dauphin’s ball.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: We must respond. This ball is an insult, to you and to your kingdom.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Remember where, as Prince, I whiled and how I spent my days.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: You spent them in considered privation.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: And drinking. Drinking and clowning. So is there not some truth in this jest? If the Dauphin wants from me a paroxysm, why give it him?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: It would not be a show of foul temper for you to respond forcefully to an insult such as this, my liege. It would be a show of strength.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: I appreciate your umbrage, William. And your loyalty. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: HAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But my strength does not lie in me flapping up and down at the slightest barb like some unholy mechanical bird. Hal focusses on the papers spread before him. William sit beside him, waiting. Hal stops, rubs his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: HAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (re the papers) Make sense of this. This is what is pressing.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: It’s most complicated, my liege. Civil strife has consumed us. War drains the purse like little else.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: This strife must end. And it will end by conciliation. We shall pardon our adversaries, Lord Scrope among them. We shall pay Mortimer’s ransom and have him returned from Wales. I will write these pardons in mine own hand. I want it known these sentiments are so personal to me. We shall let these men know they were my father’s enemies, not mine.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Certainly, my liege.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: (beat) How does this strategy greet you?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Great policy shifts are best enacted with regime change. If this is how you wish to proceed - and I will support you in that endeavour if it be so - then yes, my liege, now would be the time to do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal is with his sister, Philippa, in the palace gardens. stand at the fence of a pen holding two Bactrian camels. Philippa is enchanted. She’s never seen anything like the  42. Behind them, at respectful distance, attendants hover - s armed. Hal throws a stick for two dogs to fetch. Philippa is smiling. Their talk has been light and tender

dialogues.speaker: PHILIPPA
dialogues.text: He is kind to me. I’m happy there. I am yet to give him a child, but he seems not to mind.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: He is a good man. And you are young.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIPPA
dialogues.text: Did you reconcile with our father before his passing?

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: There was no reconciliation to be had. His passing itself was my reconciliation. He did untold harm to this kingdom. His passing will bring calm with it.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIPPA
dialogues.text: I ask not after the kingdom. What of you?

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: I want an end to this unrest. Beat. He hasn’t answered her question. Hal looks

dialogues.speaker: PHILIPPA
dialogues.text: I look around that table last night. I look at the faces of the men seated at it. And I can feel this calm of which you speak. I can see the... the hope that your vitality, and your measure, promises them. I do believe they wish you well. (beat) But I also see that they have their own kingdoms - behind their eyes... Do you understand what I say? at her.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIPPA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: These men are more than mere empty vassels awaiting your instruction.  43. Hal looks away. She searches his face, trying to read it.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIPPA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know them not. I’ve been away too Many years. And I’m now to return to Denmark. But I have in my time in that court been privy to its commissions. I have seen there, again and again, that no one ever speaks true - wholly true. Even when their intentions are virtuous, and their hopes for the realm are honourable, they are still first and foremost the sovereigns of their own kingdoms - the kingdoms of their own imagining. Hal’s shoe’s buckle has come loose. He crouches to re-fas it. Philippa stands over him. She looks at him sadly.

dialogues.speaker: PHILIPPA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Choose your steps wisely, dear brother. Tis likely not my place to offer you counsel. But that is my counsel nonetheless. Abstract as it may be. Hal looks up as Philippa wanders away. Hal watches her, suddenly feeling strangely alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Full sitting of parliament. The Archbishop has set up an easel for a presentation. On it is an incomprehensibly complicated genealogical diagram. He has performance jitt All are assembled. When Hal enters with William, all stan

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Archbishop, a presentation I’m told. A performance. The Archbishop bows. Hal sits.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHBISHOP
dialogues.text: Yes, my liege. Please, make yourself comfortable.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Comfortable. How long is this performance to be? Awkward pause. The Archbishop isn’t good at playful bante

dialogues.speaker: ARCHBISHOP
dialogues.text: I speak to King Charles of France’s claim to be the legitimate sovereign ruler of said lands. Tis - (trying to control lisp) Tis said that the law Salic would have no succession of the French crown fall to a woman. Meaning no rule left in the lineage of the female shall by rights pass to her issue. The French have long stripped such titles in favour of another whence the title was in fact left in the female thread in the absence or death of a male heir. Now, the law Salic which is of Salic land and tethered to said lands is not, ah, not therefore legally bound - or adherent at all in fact - to the lands of France... But to those of Salic. Which, as you know, lies between the lands of Elba and of Salve. I claim here, with proof, that hence it follows that the law Salic which has seen French sovereignty stolen as such from a true lineage... Thrice, as I can illuminate, the French have cited the law Salic as reason to bar a female succession -

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: With reverence?

dialogues.speaker: ARCHBISHOP
dialogues.text: Yes, my liege?

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: You have yet to introduce your extraordinary puzzle picture there and already I’m finding this story impossible to follow.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHBISHOP
dialogues.text: My liege, I question the French King’s claim to the throne upon which he sits.  45.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Is that so? What confuses me now is why you are telling me this story. The Archbishop, flummoxed, looks to others for support. Beat. Hal Beat.

dialogues.speaker: HAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Archbishop? I’m sorry. Have I muddled you?

dialogues.speaker: ARCHBISHOP
dialogues.text: My liege, I simply hope to bolster your claim to France should the need to meet her with force soon arise. is unsettled by talk of war.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: And you believe that need will indeed soon arise?

dialogues.speaker: ARCHBISHOP
dialogues.text: I, ah, my liege - by way of preparedness, I think it, I believe it always wise -

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Preparedness? If we are to war with France, it will be driven by matters hot and current. I thank you for your performance. I’m sorry to cut it short. But war will not come aS a consequence of old and impenetrable libretto.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHBISHOP
dialogues.text: France was your father’s long held ambition. Had he not been bogged in civil feud he would most surely have taken the fight to her. And then on to Jerusalem.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Jerusalem! We’re all the way to Holy Land, are we? And to sack the rest of Christendom along the way, I presume!

dialogues.speaker: ARCHBISHOP
dialogues.text: My liege -  46.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: I am not my father, Archbishop. I would have thought this clear by now. (beat, steely) Do not think me a sapling, gentlemen. Do not think I might bend to light wind. Only with a storm will I uproot. Until then... Well acted. Hal stands and leaves. The Archbishop looks stung.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal sits in an armchair, contemplative. William sits near

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: The Archbishop is a far from gifted orator.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Which is strange given I would have thought gifted oratory to be a requirement of the position. Why is the Archbishop speaking to me of war with France?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: What you are witnessing here is a stirring. Of which we must be wary. I applaud your restraint, my liege. After so many years of strife, you are proving to be more than your father’s son. And this is admirable. And sage. You wish to be a king for the people. We must ensure to that end, however, that you do not remain oblivious to the mood of the people.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: And what mood is this?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: That France is taunting us.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Do you share this mood?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: My opinion matters not. My loyalty is to you, my liege. Unwavering. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I stand by you. The mood is a fantasy. That doesn’t mean it isn’t felt true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Falstaff is squatted, doing a shit on the edge of a pile on the street. He has his garments bunched and to shoo away a persistent scavenging dog. He finishes, pulls up his breeches, and joins Beale nearby. They walk. The street is busy and filthy as

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: Why in heavens a dog would want to eat my shit I cannot fathom. Why would it not eat its own shit if it has such a taste for shit? If only I had a taste for my own shit. I'd need never search for food again.

dialogues.speaker: BEALE
dialogues.text: Dogs do eat their own shit. I seen them do it.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: Mine would be a higher order of it. If I was a shit-eating mongrel cur I s’pose I'd too want a steaming hot plate of Sir John’s blogs. 47. stink- is having waiting usual. Beale has noticed that Falstaff is walking with purpose i very particular direction.

dialogues.speaker: BEALE
dialogues.text: We can’t be going to Hooper's.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: Yes we can.

dialogues.speaker: BEALE
dialogues.text: She won’t have you.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: Yes she will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Falstaff and Beale enter the tavern. It’s busy despite th morning hour. Falstaff attempts to slink in unnoticed. He makes it half way across the room before he is.  48.

dialogues.speaker: HOOPER
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: Yes! Hooper makes her way across the room to him as he takes a seat at a table with other men.

dialogues.speaker: HOOPER
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: HOOPER
dialogues.text: You’re not welcome here. Unless you've come to pay what you owe me.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: I've paid you.

dialogues.speaker: HOOPER
dialogues.text: You've paid me a snatch of what you owe. And I presume too from the proceeds of thieving.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: Lies.

dialogues.speaker: HOOPER
dialogues.text: And so, by all account, you be not specially good at thieving neither.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: Lies. How dare you so address me. Why would you be so churlish with the very man most likely to lift you from this stinking rat-hole? Maybe you've forgot, but my associations now stretch to the highest reaches of the realm. Your insolence might as well be directed to the King himself. Ponder that now.

dialogues.speaker: HOOPER
dialogues.text: Are you speaking of Hal? Falstaff, haughty, pretends the question is beneath him.

dialogues.speaker: HOOPER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Where is he? Where is Hal? Where is our King? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: HOOPER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He be gone weeks and weeks now. Where is he? I would say you be the one who’s been forgot. I would say your dalliance with the upper reaches of the realm were short- lived in and around his stinking sick bucket. Seems you were little more than passing keeper of a prince’s puke. Ponder that now. Men at the table laugh. Falstaff is embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: BEALE
dialogues.text: Nell, Sir John is down on his luck.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: I am not.

dialogues.speaker: HOOPER
dialogues.text: You find someone to pay your way here. I’1l not be paying it for you. Hooper walks away, leaving Falstaff embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal walks at pace with two sentries. They head down a spi stair, past guards, into a dark and dank corner of the palace. A buzz in the air. Hal is concerned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal is led into the dungeon. Guards loiter. William is th William looks to the guards. They exit. Hal sits opposite GILRICH (20), an effete Frenchman in chains. [Hal and Gil will speak to each other in French, subtitled. ]

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Who are you? The man says nothing. He looks to William.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: He seeks asylum in return for his tale.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: I do not doubt this can be arranged.  50.

dialogues.speaker: GILRICH
dialogues.text: Can it or not? You are the King, no? Beat. Gilrich and Hal size each other up.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: It can be arranged.

dialogues.speaker: GILRICH
dialogues.text: I have been sent by the King of France to assassinate you.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Charles himself sent you? You know this to be certain?

dialogues.speaker: GILRICH
dialogues.text: The order's origin I know, yes. From the King.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: What was the order?

dialogues.speaker: GILRICH
dialogues.text: That I should kill the King of England.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: GILRICH
dialogues.text: However. Any way. How many ways to kill a man. Tis my talent - killing men who do not expect to be killed. Hal contemplates his prospective killer.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: In return for this admission you seek impunity and sanctuary here in England.

dialogues.speaker: GILRICH
dialogues.text: Oui. Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal with William, Dorset, Cambridge, Grey, Westmorland - Scrope, newly returned from his rebel defection.

dialogues.speaker: DORSET
dialogues.text: This is an act of war.  51.

dialogues.speaker: SCROPE
dialogues.text: The man we have chained now is but a coward. Maybe he was too low paid. Whatever his grievance, he was sent. Which means another may come. And I fear the next may be of firmer mettle than the weasel that nests in the dungeon beneath our feet.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: At such a time as I endeavour to foster a fresh and peaceful air for this kingdom to breathe, it is not in my interest to stir hostility with another. I would expect you, Lord Scrope, to understand this as well as any other. I have welcomed you back to this court so as to forge quite the opposite of whatever bellicose fever it was that had you turn your arms against it. Scrope looks at Hal with defiance. He has indeed been welcomed back - only to be shut down. William breaks tens

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Understand we do, my liege, but - with respect - to ignore such an audacious act of aggression will be seen as weakness. This is no game ball. This is an assassin.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Would you consider me weak, Chief Justice?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Certainly not, my liege. No. I see the honour in your intent. I speak more of the kingdom, of what the kingdom sees.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Of what the kingdom sees. And how, pray, might the kingdom see the weasel beneath our feet?  Hal feels Hal looks 52.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: That weasel is a pimple. If France’s animus towards you runs deep enough for them to send an assassin, then it will be felt in the streets, ours and theirs. It will be known. his leadership tested. The other men wait and watch.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We share your concerns, my liege. We share your longing for peace. But the stability of peace today needs more than harmony. It needs strength and confidence. These are qualities that can originate only in you, the King. They must be seen - and felt. at William. He thinks. He turns to an attendant.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Take down these words, addressed to King Charles of France. Hal takes the ball from the Dauphin’s chest. He bounces i twice, on his desk.

dialogues.speaker: HAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This assassin you send can be taken as nothing other than an infant act of war. If this be your intention, I say you let it be known plainly and honourably and that you desist from the timorous slither in which you presently engage. If it be war you seek, send the full weight of your army, for a lone and cowardly assassin will not topple this King Henry the Fifth of England you so underestimate. Hal lifts the chest and empties the tennis balls on the floor. He drops the chest back on his desk.

dialogues.speaker: HAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fill this with gun-stones and send it back to France.  53.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal, on his throne. A full sitting of parliament. A speec being given. Hal, half-listening, searches the faces of t men before him. All inscrutable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal alone, on his knees at the altar, deep in prayer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All is ominously still. The sky the colour of blood. EXT. CAMBRIDGE’S ESTATE - EVENING A stately manor house in last light. A carriage pulls up outside it. A man alights, looking around warily. INT. CAMBRIDGE’S ESTATE - EVENING Cambridge steps into the entrance hall to meet his STEWAR the front door. Cambridge’s children are in the kitchen behind him. There is a wary tension in the air.

dialogues.speaker: CAMBRIDGE
dialogues.text: Who is it? CAMBRIDGE’S STEWARD A Frenchman, sire. He says he wishes to speak with you privately.

dialogues.speaker: CAMBRIDGE
dialogues.text: About what? CAMBRIDGE’S STEWARD He wouldn't say, sire. I asked of him. He wouldn’t say. INT. PRIVATE CHAMBERS / CAMBRIDGE’S ESTATE - NIGHT The man, a French ENVOY, takes a seat in Cambridge’s sitt chamber. He waits for the attendant to leave before speak

dialogues.speaker: ENVOY
dialogues.text: My King has sent me to seek out men he feels he can trust. He believes there is discreet discussion to be had.  54.

dialogues.speaker: CAMBRIDGE
dialogues.text: What discussion?

dialogues.speaker: ENVOY
dialogues.text: He believes there is discussion to be had about your new King of England. Cambridge realises he is now in a precarious position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cambridge and Grey with William in a quiet corner.

dialogues.speaker: CAMBRIDGE
dialogues.text: Only myself and Lord Grey were met. We knew not where to turn... about what was spoken to us. Nervous, he looks to Grey who stands, eager to cut the fu

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: We are all of us aware that there is a standing problem. Our King is of low repute.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: The French King teaches you this? Is he not thankful for young Henry’s light reaction to his provocations? Or does he come on spoiling?

dialogues.speaker: CAMBRIDGE
dialogues.text: The assassin he swears he knows not of. Tis a charge he denies.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: The plot came to nought. Of course he would wish to wipe his hands of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whatever the root, they have expressed grave concern regarding our King’s mental fortitude and what it might mean for relations between our kingdoms. William thinks, watches Cambridge.

dialogues.speaker: CAMBRIDGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I myself once counted His Majesty a brother, but, my lord, as you say, much has -

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Is the envoy to be trusted?

dialogues.speaker: CAMBRIDGE
dialogues.text: I believe so. As if you yourself were to voyage on Henry’s behalf.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Charles wishes to dethrone our King.

dialogues.speaker: CAMBRIDGE
dialogues.text: They have proffered no course of action. They merely wish to establish that their concern is mutually held.

dialogues.speaker: GREY
dialogues.text: The issue is not France. This is but a reminder to us of a more general lunacy. A man who but weeks ago was a drunken boor from the sewers of Eastcheap now wears England's crown... What shall become of us? What shall become of us when civil misdeeds are forgiven as if they were but indiscretions? When traitors are invited to rejoin the court as if they had been but away on sojourn? When it appears -

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Yes. These concerns are current and numerous. Something must be done... And something will be done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal is seated. William stands beside his desk.  56.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Thus is the King’s burden. A king must make decisions lesser men are neither willing nor able to make. A king is indeed presented with quandaries lesser men might never encounter in the course of their whole lives. Hal drops his head, stares at the floor.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I wish it were not so. But problems, my liege - this is my experience - problems left unattended have a habit of becoming crises. You have a chance here to unite this land truly. You have refreshed its mood with promise. But promise must be fulfilled. Promise can never be an end in itself. Pause, Hal looking at the floor, thinking.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: One does not secure the integrity of his house by ignoring the woodworm... (looks up at William) Nor by attempting to make peace with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The full court gathered, chatting casually. William on ed Hal enters, steely. The men go silent as they notice him.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: As of this day we are at war with France. Stunned silence. Grey and Cambridge shuffle nervously.

dialogues.speaker: HAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Twice I have given her the benefit of my doubt. Once as a trifling joust which I paid. The second I met with messaged caution. This third will not be left unchecked.  57.

dialogues.speaker: DORSET
dialogues.text: (beat, cautious) What be this latest provocation to arouse thy fury, my liege?

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: And so in order to flush these French rats from their nests, I will have it communicated to them that we are now at war. Hal stares strangely at the men.

dialogues.speaker: HAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And who do we propose might deliver this declaration? An envoy. A man or men of high standing. Hal steps directly to Cambridge and Grey.

dialogues.speaker: HAL, (CONT'D)
