dialogues.text: Lords Grey and Cambridge. I would ask you deliver this message to France given your familiarity with its recipient, but I believe in the morning you be otherwise engaged. Cambridge, nervous, waits for Hal to continue. Hal doesn’

dialogues.speaker: CAMBRIDGE
dialogues.text: Pray how, my liege? Hal looks him square in the eye. It’s deep and personal.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Tomorrow you will have your heads axed off. I have chosen to send you as an advance party to Hell for the considerable French number that will soon be needing to find space there. Hal looks at Cambridge. The room is pin-drop still.

dialogues.speaker: HAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You were once my friend. Cambridge is stunned, bewildered.

dialogues.speaker: CAMBRIDGE
dialogues.text: I am your friend. Hal moves away. Grey looks to William who watches him col  55 58.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cambridge and Grey on a platform - before them a beheadin block. Abject fear on their faces. The full court gathered. Hal and William watch, steely. A guard pushes Grey forward and onto his knees, his neck the block. Grey breathes hard, hyperventilating.

dialogues.speaker: CLERGYMAN
dialogues.text: May God take pity on you. A moment passes. Strange silence. The HEADSMAN swings his axe. Grey’s head comes off. Blood gushes. Hal watches, an then meets Cambridge’s terrified and confused eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tavern is busy. Noise, loud voices in a confined spac The door opens. Six armed and masked guards enter and sta ominously at the entrance. The noise dies quickly.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: All leave. Now. Scoundrels grab their cloaks and make their way hastily t the door. They file timidly out past the guards. Falstaff sits at a far table, watching warily. He takes h scarf and goes to make a quiet exit.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You. Stay. Falstaff sits again, weighing his options as the room emp Hostess Hooper remains at a table. A guard points at her.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You. Leave.

dialogues.speaker: HOOPER
dialogues.text: This is my place. A hooded figure walks in and stops at the top of the stai

dialogues.speaker: HOODED MAN
dialogues.text: The hostess can stay. The man removes his hood. It’s Hal. He steps in. He appro Falstaff. Falstaff remains wary, watching Hal suspiciousl  59.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: That’s my welcome?

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: You want me to curtsey? That could take a while, with my funny knee and all. First I’d have to stand. Then I’d have to bend over. We could be here all night. I think I'll just stay sitting if it suits Your Highness. Hal places a purse of coins on the table for Hooper.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: For the loss of patronage. (to Falstaff) I beg a moment of your time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal and Falstaff sit at a corner table. Falstaff drinks a

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: I expect nothing of you. I am here to ask. Simply.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: And simply I refuse. I won’t jump to your attention, and surely not to retread vile ground I vowed I would never walk again. A man who has found it so easy to shed his skin should find wholly sensible the sentiments of this here snake. Hal can clearly sense Falstaff’s underlying hurt feelings

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: I acknowledge my neglect of you, John. I regret it deeply. A new chapter of my life was begun before the last could be properly closed.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: Why won’t you drink with me? Hal pauses, not sure if the question is a thaw in tension

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Drinking is what men do when they wish to take temporary leave from life. I no longer have this luxury.  60. Falstaff drinks and smiles to himself.

dialogues.speaker: HAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Already I can feel the weight of this crown I wear. I know you remember, I once wished to eschew both its burden and its pretensions. But to do so now would be cowardice. It is incumbent upon me to steer a course for the defence and the betterment of England. This is that course. (beat) These concerns are mine and mine alone. But the fact that this here, now, be the first occasion I’ve had to sound them aloud to anyone other than myself speaks volumes. It speaks to the loneliness of the position in which I find myself. To steer our present course I’ve been forced to rely upon the counsel of men whose loyalty I question every waking moment. Every waking moment. I need around me men I trust beyond doubt - and of them there is only one on this earth I can identify with anything near certainty. Hal looks to Falstaff with humility. Falstaff reads it.

dialogues.speaker: HAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I expect nothing of you, John. Whatever decision you make I will respect without question. But I’m here because I love you and because at this point, in this chapter, I need that love like I need the air I breathe. I’m here because you are my friend.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: A king has no friends. A king has only followers and foe. The moment hangs heavy. Hal stands and dons his cloak.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: I’m sorry that my occasion to visit carries with it this doleful weight. Falstaff watches him, unmoved. Hal heads for the exit. Th  61.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: Hal. Hal stops and turns.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I will come with you. Beat. Hal watches him.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I ask only one favour in return. The moment is loaded. Falstaff points to Hooper.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Square my account with this terrible hag, would you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal walks a line of assembled men. The full court plus th Duke of York and handful of others.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: We welcome those newly arrived here. Sir Daffydd from Wales. He comes face to face with the noblemen one by one.

dialogues.speaker: HAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Cousin Westmorland. Lords Warrick and Dorset... Great men all. Turn us now in common poise, with one mind, sharpened. Let past grievances be forgot. Our minds make free to one end. Together we will bring France down. Together we will bring her to her knees. (beat) Captains all, to this end, I introduce you to a new marshal of our campaign. Hal pauses. Anticipation.

dialogues.speaker: HAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sir John Falstaff. Falstaff steps forward, strangely polite and nervous. He wears the best outfit he could muster at short notice. He looks out of place, but clean and combed and strong.  62. The other men in the room are confused. William is unsett

dialogues.speaker: HAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sir John's experience in battle should need no recitation. You know of him. Some of you have had the honour of fighting alongside him. Others have heard tale of his exploits and his bravery, of his redoubtable command of men. But I have tasked Sir John to join this campaign for one most vital reason alone: he respects war as only a man who has seen its most monstrous form can. He lusts after it not, but rather regards it with the grim sobriety that you and your men should hope he would. You will listen to him as you would to me. He is my eyes and my ears, my heart and my head. Falstaff, on long-estranged ground, feels rusty. Hal look him to speak, which he does without fuss or flower.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: Welcome and thank you, good sirs. You are all well met.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Falstaff is in a bathtub. A pageboy sits on a stool besid the tub massaging Falstaff’s foot which hangs over its ed He looks uncomfortable. Falstaff scrubs his armpit. He squirms and laughs.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: Hard. Not soft. Hard. Be forceful. A knock at the door.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Enter! The door opens. Hal enters. He takes in the scene. He clo the door behind him and takes a seat near the tub. FALSTAFF (CONT’D) I’m having to explain to this stripling that a soft scrub of the foot might be construed in some circles as a tickle.  63. Hal is unsettled by Falstaff’s drunken jocularity.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Are you ready for what awaits us?

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: One is never ready for what awaits us.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Do you prepare yourself as best you might? Falstaff knows Hal needs reassurance. He sobers a pinch.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: You know me well. I see first to the fettle of my humours. My wits depend on it. As do yours. I counsel you follow my lead. Hal smiles wearily. He’s tired. He looks at the pageboy w his head bowed. He stands and heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Rest well, my liege.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Under a foreboding sky, a hundred men load supplies into crates on the backs of horse-drawn drays. Blacksmiths ham and solder. Stockpiles of armour and weaponry are sorted. Macabre instruments of death and destruction. The dirty industrial end of the war machine. An imposing enterprise Around a corner, Falstaff is with two lowly conscripts.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: I can’t understand the garble coming out your mouth hole.

dialogues.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogues.text: We don’t want to get on that ship for no war or such.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: You don’t want to get on that ship for no war or such.

dialogues.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogues.text: We know you got the position to get us off it now. We don’t want to go to no war in France.  64.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: So while other men - few of whom I imagine want to go to war - do so anyway, for their good King has called to them, you imagine I should grant you some form of official exemption on account of your simply not wanting to ‘go to no war in France or such’. Have I understood you? And what might be the benefit for me? In the gross violation of order such sympathetic dispensation would constitute?

dialogues.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: Coin, brownface. What coin have you? The conscript pulls a sack of coins from his filthy pocke

dialogues.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogues.text: This. Falstaff takes the sack and starts counting coins discree

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: What are your names?

dialogues.speaker: HAMMOND
dialogues.text: Hammond and Horland. I’m Hammond and he’s Horland.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: I don’t care which one of you is which. Falstaff finishes his count and pockets the sack.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Right. Piss off now, Hammond and Horland. Hammond and Horland scurry away. As Falstaff heads back r to the main yard, he looks up and waves to someone. Looking on from across the yard, Hal stands watching the industry. He nods reply to Falstaff’s wave. William is be him. Hal looks concerned.  65.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: My liege, I must ask. You believe Sir John to be fit and suitable enough to captain this effort? Hal lets this sit. The ugly weapons being prepared and pa portend only blood and death.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: This is what we have set in motion. I must know that it will be captained by men of good intent - above all else. There are few of whom I know it clear and true. (beat, looks at William) You might be the only other, William. You're a man of good intent. But you’re not a soldier. Hal looks back down at the war preparations.

dialogues.speaker: HAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: John is a good man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Above deck, Hal with William, Dorset and Falstaff, a map out before them. Hal is deep in thought. The other men wa him. Beyond, a huge flotilla of English ships on the chan

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: We shall know soon enough. They meet us at sea or upon our landing - we shall know all in the morning. You must rest. Hal rubs his face deeply. The men rise to leave.

dialogues.speaker: HAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: John. As the men file down a ladder to the lower deck, Falstaff waits. Hal looks at him. Falstaff, about to break the sil

dialogues.speaker: HAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thank you. Hal clearly had something else to say, but couldn’t find

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: For what?  66.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: For being here. With me.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: Small price to pay to get that detestable Hooper woman off my back. Hal smiles sadly.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You too should rest, my liege. Falstaff smiles, nods and climbs the ladder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Falstaff steps down below deck, dark and cramped with men roams among them - trepidation, outright fear on their fa an eerie quiet under the ship’s creak and groan. Falstaff puts his hand on shoulders, makes much eye conta These looks he has seen on many faces before - the looks men who wonder if their remaining lives might now be coun in hours. He tries to reassure with his calm smile, but k nothing can ever truly assuage their feelings. He takes a seat on a sack of grain at the end of a row of hammocks. He folds his arms, watches the men a moment lon then closes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fog. A boat grinds its bow onto the sand. Hal and Falstaf in light armour, jump into knee deep water and wade ashor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over the dunes, Hal, Falstaff, Dorset and a collection of twenty or so men-at-arms walk warily between seemingly abandoned farm buildings. They tread lightly, swords draw Two soldiers act as point men ahead. Terrifying stillness. No one speaks. The town feels fresh abandoned. The mist drifts like smoke through it. A lone donkey wanders aimless. The men watch it warily.  67. On the rise beyond, a castle looms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Light rain. The English have set up a makeshift camp on t outskirts of Harfleur. Thousands of men and horses. Giant trebuchets are being assembled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal with Falstaff, William, Dorset, Scrope and Westmorlan They sit by a fire under a canopy slung from a tent.

dialogues.speaker: DORSET
dialogues.text: We must storm that castle. It will be bloody. We will most surely sacrifice souls. Thus is the nature of war. It is bloody and soulless. Hal listens, thinking.

dialogues.speaker: DORSET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If circumstances were other, we might hold this place to siege, but I fear the march of time is our second enemy. We have no way of knowing how well supplied they are behind those walls. A siege may take months, and months, I fear, we have not at our disposal. Our force is too large to sustain a lengthy siege. We must move. Men in these numbers fixed here will fall to hunger and disease. Hal takes this in, then looks to Falstaff. Falstaff spits

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: War is bloody and soulless. Hal looks to the dirt at his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The now assembled trebuchets - huge wooden machines of medieval warfare - are being armed by English soldiers, working by the light of giant bonfires. Once loaded, each trebuchet hurls a terrifying fireball through the dark ac the field, to crash into the castle’s walls. Hal stands and watches while fires burn all around him.  68.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rain has eased, but the sky is grey and the ground mu Men are already looking cold, wasted, forlorn. Some eat s Hal, William and Falstaff stand watching the trebuchets continue their horrible bombardment on the castle on the hill. Smoke billows from within the walls.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: The Archbishop has arrived. From the beach below, a small retinue of soldiers approac Leading them is the Archbishop. Attendants accompany him, holding a canopy over his head. Hal watches them waddle through the mud in full silly clerical regalia.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHBISHOP
dialogues.text: Your Majesty, tis good to see you well!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal, Falstaff, William and Dorset sit with the Archbishop

dialogues.speaker: ARCHBISHOP
dialogues.text: Surely you can not simply idle here until they decide to come out?

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: That's precisely the definition of a siege.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHBISHOP
dialogues.text: How long might that take? Surely there is no way of knowing.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: That too is a common characteristic of a siege.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: I will not send my men up that hill.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHBISHOP
dialogues.text: But why in heavens not?

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: I will not sacrifice my men so flagrantly, nor so speculatively.  69.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHBISHOP
dialogues.text: This is war. Men die in war. Hal lets this sit. He watches the Archbishop coldly.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: How fortunate you are to find its horrors so unexceptional.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHBISHOP
dialogues.text: Well then why do you not simply go around? If they insist on hiding in their castle, why do you not simply go around it? Let them hide. Hiding is an admission of defeat. Take it as such and we can press on. Hal looks to Falstaff and William to share his bewildered disdain. He turns back to the Archbishop.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: And so well versed in the art of warfare. Hal stands and exits the tent.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (to Archbishop) We must take this town. We must establish a garrison foothold here for our lines of supply from England. Simply ignoring the force behind those walls is entirely untenable. The Archbishop is uncomfortable speaking candidly in Falstaff’s presence.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHBISHOP
dialogues.text: We must expedite these concerns, my lords. You understand this. Do not forget that I have underwritten this campaign. I have interest here. And I will be heard. Beat. William stands and exits. The Archbishop is left to squirm under Falstaff’s stare.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal walks between tents. He is startled by the sound of a distant horn. Westmorland approaches out of breath.  70.

dialogues.speaker: WESTMORLAND
dialogues.text: My liege... They have surrendered. William walks to them. Hal turns to him.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Our debate now it seems is irrelevant. The distant horn blows again. Hal smiles.

dialogues.speaker: HAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: As are the Archbishop’s bleatings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dorset, Scrope, Westmorland, the Archbishop and William s beside Hal who sits on his throne under a canopy. The CAPTAIN OF HARFLEUR, JEAN D’ESTOUTEVILLE, genuflects before him. D’ESTOUTEVILE (in French, subtitled) The day is yours. We ask only that our women and children be freed. There are already many hungry and wounded and becoming sick.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: (in French, subtitled) Upon full account of the castle, I see no reason to deny your request. You will have tonight to oversee this evacuation and to corral your men prisoners. Lord Scrope will oversee this night and take full possession of the castle in the morning. D’Estouteville stands and nods. Scrope escorts him away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Falstaff moves through the filthy camp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Falstaff enters. Hal is with William, Westmorland and Dor Hal is on his throne.  71.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I am told it would be but a day before his arrival. Perchance two.

dialogues.speaker: DORSET
dialogues.text: He wishes to slow us.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: Who wishes to slow us?

dialogues.speaker: WESTMORLAND
dialogues.text: We have received word that the Dauphin is en route. He wishes conference with His Highness.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: We know nothing of his purpose?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: We know only that he desires conference. I would hope his purpose be to deliver his father’s early surrender.

dialogues.speaker: DORSET
dialogues.text: I strongly advise we disregard this word of his approach and ready our movement. The Dauphin will be in haste cobbling a bickering army from all corners. We mustn’t let him dally us. We must make advantage of their disarray. All wait for Hal to speak. Hal turns to Falstaff.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Sir John, please, your counsel. The men look to Falstaff. He shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: I’ve never met the man, this French Prince. I can’t speak to his motivation. The men wait for more from Falstaff. None is coming.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: We wait one day more. After this, the Prince can deliver his message to us on the move.  72. INT. HAL’S TENT / HARFLEUR TOWN OUTSKIRTS - NIGHT Hal is asleep in his bed. The Lord Chamberlain is asleep the floor. William enters.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: My liege. Forgive me. Hal stirs awake.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He’s here. Can you smell him? He has doused himself in perfume.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The French Prince, THE DAUPHIN, LOUIS, DUKE OF GUYENNE, s on Hal’s throne, laughing with his men. Hal and William enter. Falstaff, Westmorland and Dorset are already there The Dauphin is dressed ostentatiously, flamboyant, vain.

dialogues.speaker: DAUPHIN
dialogues.text: Your Majesty! Excuse the hour. I have never visited here before. I find we have lost our way. Hal assays the Dauphin and his men.

dialogues.speaker: DAUPHIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Please, sit. Or I beg your pardon. He stands.

dialogues.speaker: DAUPHIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You must invite me, of course. This is your domain. Hal doesn’t move. The Dauphin sits again, raises his cup.

dialogues.speaker: DAUPHIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: To your little victory. Hal stares.

dialogues.speaker: DAUPHIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you wonder why I have come? The Dauphin looks to Hal, then to William and Falstaff, t back to Hal. He raises his eyebrows.  73.

dialogues.speaker: DAUPHIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you wonder this? Hal stares impassively at the Dauphin.

dialogues.speaker: DAUPHIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I have not come to offer you surrender if that is what you were hoping. I have come instead to describe for you your end days, the screams of your men as they die slow. The Dauphin stares at Hal, trying to be intimidating.

dialogues.speaker: DAUPHIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And so, King of England, you seem so intent on making France your new home, I will help you. I will drain your body of its blood and I will bury it under a tree. A little French tree. Very young and small. Since perchance that is fitting of your mind to come here. Small. And Maybe your - He gestures to his cock.

dialogues.speaker: DAUPHIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But no, your balls must be big. His humour is forced. He smiles a gloating smile to his m

dialogues.speaker: DAUPHIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: A tiny little cock. And giant balls! The Dauphin laughs falsely and loudly, then sobers.

dialogues.speaker: DAUPHIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And the sound of your wives and children weeping I will use to lull me to sleep at night. Oh, but of course there is no one for you? To weep for you? No wife or children? No? I might just use that thought to lull me to sleep at night. Falstaff yawns wide and loud. The Dauphin is taken aback.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: Pardon me. Hal stares dully at the Dauphin.  74.

dialogues.speaker: DAUPHIN
dialogues.text: Have you heard what I have said?

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: I have. It was stirring. (to Falstaff) Sir John, walk with me. Falstaff nods and stands. Hal puts his hand on William’s shoulder and smiles to the room.

dialogues.speaker: HAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Good night, all.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Good night, Your Majesty. Hal exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal and Falstaff walk between tents. Hal is dark and focussed.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Ready the men to move. Waste no time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal rides the length of his massive army train. Weary men Many are sick with dysentery - archers, food carriages, masons, livestock. And shackled French prisoners on foot. A carriage carries the Archbishop. He smiles as Hal passe Hal ignores him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal, Falstaff and Dorset at a forest’s edge. They are joi by William, and attendants.

dialogues.speaker: DORSET
dialogues.text: We must cross these woodlands. We drift still further north if we stay along that road. Hal turns to Falstaff who shakes his head.  75.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: I don’t like the smell of these woods. They smell of French prince. Hal looks into the dense thicket. Falstaff smells the air

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Peculiar smell it is. Falstaff ambles off. Hal watches him. Dorset boils.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure enough, the Dauphin and a handful of his soldiers hi on the forested rise of the hill flanking the crossing. H watches the English move on. He spits and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The English in full swing making camp. Tents are raised. Hammers post pegs. Horses are freed of their saddles. Hal sits on a crate and pulls his boots off. He looks aro Men cough and collapse exhausted. Three BOY ATTENDANTS leave the camp to gather wood and wa Two carry axes, one a pail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boys wander through the forest. Shafts of light throu the trees. The sound of the bubbling river. Moments later - two of the boys gather kindling. Meanwhile, the third boy gets to the river’s edge. He sco water into his pail. When he stands, a figure holding a dagger appears behind him. A hand reaches around and grab his mouth. He is stabbed through the spine. The noise - Alerts the other boys 30 yards away. They drop their kind and run. Two more French soldiers give chase, one with a crossbow. One of the boys is dropped by a crossbow bolt. The other runs straight into The Dauphin, standing in wai with another soldier. The Dauphin’s face is camouflaged with charcoal.  76. He crouches before the frightened boy.

dialogues.speaker: DAUPHIN
dialogues.text: (in English) Hello, little boy. The boy is practically paralysed with fear.

dialogues.speaker: DAUPHIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don’t be afraid. Strange beat. The Dauphin looks the boy over, studies his face. The boy’s fear is mounting, tearful, sickening.

dialogues.speaker: DAUPHIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hush now, small one. Don’t be afraid. You will live. I shall have you deliver a gift to your king. He strokes the kid’s hair.

dialogues.speaker: DAUPHIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Will you do that for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tight on the blonde boy’s traumatised face as he walks sl out of the forest and back into camp. At the edge of camp men notice him and stand back in horror. The boy carries the severed head of the pail boy. INT. HAL’S TENT / RIVERSIDE CAMPSITE - MOMENTS LATER Hal sits boiling. Falstaff watches him.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Double the guards to twenty yards through the night. Three hours at a watch. I want these men fresh and alert. Any man caught sleeping will have his eyes gouged. Any caught speaking will lose his tongue. He looks at Falstaff. Falstaff stands.

dialogues.speaker: HAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And I want all French prisoners in our train put to death. Leave their corpses speared on pikes by the river's edge.  77.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: I will heed the first command. The second - you'll need to carry out that mass execution yourself.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: What did you say to me?

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: You are not that man.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: How dare you?

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: Show your feeling in here, with me. But do not let it leave this tent.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: How dare you defy me? I am your king. I should have you killed alongside those shackled French pigs. Hal breaths hard, looking at Falstaff with venom.

dialogues.speaker: HAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And where is the fearsome old warrior about whom I’ve heard so much, that trumpeted his battle- smarts to me so loudly? You’ve been mute since we crossed the sea. I seem to be serving as my own chief tactician, my own commander, my own counsel. Where is the great warrior Falstaff? Beat. Falstaff is calm. He watches Hal fume.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: I speak only when there is something to be said. Too often have I seen men of war invent work for themselves, work that leads to nought but vainglory and slaughtered men. I am not that man. And this here is the war you have chosen to wage. Hal charges Falstaff, collars him, a knife to his throat.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: I will disembowel you right here with mine own hand.  78. Falstaff stares coolly into Hal’s eyes.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: You’re not that man either. They hold a look. Hal fumes, then backs down. Falstaff ex

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The air is muted. Men are in shock. Some stare into fires Others lie still. Somewhere in the shadows, a man sobs. Falstaff roams among them. He lugs a bottle. He’s drunk. has a wild look in his eye. He stumbles upon three men kneeling in prayer, eyes close He sits and watches them quietly. They finish. Amen. They open their eyes. They notice Falstaff. They bow their hea

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: Have you ever had cause to hear the Archbishop of Canterbury speak? None answer.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s quite a show. You're prostrated there already. I shall sermonise. I’ll render it for you. Falstaff looks around. He finds a bucket. He puts it on h head upended like the Archbishop’s mitre. He exaggerates Archbishop's lisp, tongue hanging from his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And the Lord saideth, I knoweth thou hath savour for spelt and sorrel and steer steaks with juices and sauces. But I give you this, my sacred promise: I will summons a great pestilence, carried by serpents on floodwaters - such unspeakable suffering, unspeakable suffering, from which there shall be no succour - should you forsake the simple sausage. The men smile wide, try to contain their laughter.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And know that when this pestilence comes, it comes not to smite thee for thine past sins committed. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It comes because thou’st forsook my unassailable love for sausages. Men laugh. More gather. Falstaff hands off his bottle.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And when thou’st can find no sausages, thou’st must take to the seas in ships - sailing ships, splendid sailing vessels! - so as to search for delicious fishes of all descriptions. Salty sea creatures and shellfish to be savoured with sesame and, ah, ah -—

dialogues.speaker: SOMEONE
dialogues.text: Spinach.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: Spinach! Yes, indeed! Spinaci! - Falstaff chokes and laughs and chokes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Falstaff rides in his forward position. He hones his eyes through the trees around them. He knows the French are cl Hal rides up to take his position. The look they exchange cold. The air is tense. The men are eerily silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The English train crosses a swamp. Horses wade. Men strug to keep their supplies from tumbling into the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train has halted. Hal, William, Dorset and Falstaff survey the field before them. Pristine countryside. A gen slope to a small hill on its far side. Dense forest to th right and left, but in between - a huge empty tranquil fi

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Dorset, summon your fastest rider.

dialogues.speaker: DORSET
dialogues.text: Yes, my liege.  80. Dorset turns to his ATTENDANTS nearby.

dialogues.speaker: DORSET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Dartmouth. DARTMOUTH (20), skinny like a jockey, trots to the group.

dialogues.speaker: DARTMOUTH
dialogues.text: Sires. What can I do for ye? Hal points to the crest of the far hill.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Tell me what lies over that hill. Ride fast and return directly. Dartmouth spurs his horse. The men watch him cross the fi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dartmouth rides hard into the wind as he crests the hill. At the top, over the other side, he can see thousands of Frenchmen - an army lying in wait. An intimidating sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Passions high. William sits quiet. Falstaff eats an apple

dialogues.speaker: DORSET
dialogues.text: We are both outnumbered and out- positioned. They have the down- slope in their favour. Our need to advance puts us already at disadvantage.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: The longer we wait, the larger their force will grow. And with it our disadvantage. Your archers, my lord, are of superior faculty. French crossbows are no match for an English longbow. We should hobble their number on first assault by these means alone.

dialogues.speaker: DORSET
dialogues.text: York's charge in centre faces four lines of mounted knights. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: DORSET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Three of men-at-arms. Our archers here might weaken those by half. But not eight lines. Nine. Ten. More. Hal can’t argue with this.

dialogues.speaker: DORSET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You speak true, my liege. The longer we wait, the greater our disadvantage. But it is possible our disadvantage has already grown insurmountable. A great many men are already desperately ill and weak from hunger.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: (challenging) What then, my Lord, do you propose we do?

dialogues.speaker: DORSET
dialogues.text: (beat) I propose we consider turning back, my liege. To return again at a later date, stronger, better prepared. Hal stares defiantly, but knows opinion runs against him.

dialogues.speaker: DORSET, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I know it will not bring the outcome we desire, but nor will the evisceration of our army. I’m reticent to speak for others here now, but I’m certain my fears are shared. Hal looks at Dorset a moment longer, then -

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Who here agrees with Lord Dorset? Silence. No one will admit to it. Hal looks around the ci Men avoid his eyes. The silence lingers. Until -

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: We can win this battle. All turn to Falstaff. He lets the attention soak in. He c his mouthful of apple.

dialogues.speaker: DORSET
dialogues.text: Is that so, Sir John?  82.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: Yes. Dorset’s patience with Falstaff has worn thin.

dialogues.speaker: DORSET
dialogues.text: And precisely how is it so, Sir John?

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: We fight without horses and without armour. Dorset throws his arms in the air and looks to the sky.

dialogues.speaker: DORSET
dialogues.text: Heavens above! Please spare us from this man.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: Their forward defence is a frontline of mounted men, many deep. Knights all. All on horseback, all in heavy armour. The ground down there is a floodplain, already half-sodden. And when the rain falls again tonight, as I know it will, that ground will turn to a muddy bog. With their horses and their armour, they will get stuck, they will fall and they will flounder like upturned beetles.

dialogues.speaker: WESTMORLAND
dialogues.text: As shall we.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: Not if we travel light, without horses and without armour. Speed and mobility will be our advantage. We will pick them off like lame cattle and that great mound of fallen French knights will serve as our battlement.

dialogues.speaker: WESTMORLAND
dialogues.text: And how on earth can you be sure of rainfall tonight?

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: My left knee is aching - it only does that when rain is near.  83.

dialogues.speaker: DORSET
dialogues.text: Oh, save us! My liege, please, put a stop to this drivel.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: (ignoring Dorset) This would require their armoured frontline come meet us in the mud. How do you propose we invite that?

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: A small forward armoured attack of our own. A false advance. They will counter. We save our weight and muscle for a nimble assault from the flanks.

dialogues.speaker: DORSET
dialogues.text: They shan’t be so easily deceived. They will not respond to false attack. Dorset shakes his head, incredulous. Falstaff smiles and then, suddenly, tosses his apple to Dorset. Dorset reacts startled, catches the apple.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: They will respond. He has their full attention. Dorset fumes, drops the appl

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We move, they will meet us in the mud. Our men-at-arms are outnumbered. This they know. They will hope to overwhelm us and so will meet us with full force, no matter how small our first advance. Our great longbows will rain chaos upon them from above. That chaos will be our favour. Hal ponders this, searching Falstaff's eyes for motivatio

dialogues.speaker: DORSET
dialogues.text: My liege. I implore you. We mustn’t listen to this madness. What is the true experience of this man? He once fought for Richard. Many years ago. Since then he has done nothing other than ride with the companies, robbing and tormenting.  84.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: I never robbed anyone who didn’t deserve to be robbed. Beat. Hal looks only at Falstaff.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: If it rains tonight, we fight tomorrow. EXT. FALSTAFF’S TENT / AGINCOURT - NIGHT Falstaff sits alone by a fire outside his tent, short of friends. Hal sits beside him and stares into the flame.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: If you have concocted this plan, half-baked and speculative, merely to prove to me your worth, please say so now.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: All plans are speculative, my liege.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Please, John, do not call me that when we’re alone. It makes me feel as though we are living a fiction.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: Are we not? A loaded moment. Hal drops his eyes, penitent.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Though you might not think it possible, you are my friend. Falstaff stokes the fire. For Hal, a disconsolate moment. Falstaff eases it.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: All plans are speculative. And as I say, I only speak them when I can feel them true. This one I feel in my bones. This one I can feel in my kneebone. He smiles. Hal shares it. Silence. Hal stares into the fi  85.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Here we are on the eve of this fight, and I’m scared to wonder, to tell it true, why we are even here.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: You best discover the answer to that for yourself. The men out there deserve it. These are the men are who are still here. These are the men that tried not to bribe their way home, that chose not to run to their villages to hide. These men are your willing shadows. They've given their lives over to you. (beat) I can’t say I know what forces have conspired to bring you here, but these men need you, just as you need them. These men deserve your confidence. If you can not give them that, at least then tell them a magnificent lie.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Why are you here?

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: I’m here because you asked me to come. Falstaff looks at Hal warmly, then pats Hal’s leg and sta

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Good night, Hal. Sleep well. Falstaff steps inside his tent, leaving Hal alone. Hal looks out over the sprawling camp - small fires dotte among clumps of cold and tired men, shadows in the dark. INT/EXT. FALSTAFF’S TENT / AGINCOURT - DAWN Falstaff wakes. The sound of light rain on the tent. He steps outside, looks to the sky, feels the drops on hi face. He crouches before an old chest. He unlatches and opens i Inside is a suit of heavy armour. He lifts out a helmet. brushes dust off it and regards it wistfully.  86. INT/EXT. HAL’S TENT / AGINCOURT - MORNING Hal, kneeling in prayer. The Lord Chamberlain stands quie by. Hal stands and exits his tent. William is waiting outside. They survey the camp, beginni its preparations.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Is this folly?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: As you say, my liege, I am not a soldier. Tis not for me to question your instinct. I can advise on strategy, not tactic. I would say I fear the pall it should cast on the vigour of your fresh crown were we to return home today. To be sure, defeat here might cast that same pall. Retreat would guarantee it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In amongst the wider battle preparations around the camp, Westmorland briefs a contingent of twenty knights, seated standing and rumbling with disquiet.

dialogues.speaker: WESTMORLAND
dialogues.text: These are the King’s orders. We are to fight unarmoured, and without chargers.

dialogues.speaker: KNIGHT
dialogues.text: We are to be sacrificed. Is that what he asks of us?

dialogues.speaker: WESTMORLAND
dialogues.text: His belief is that fighting unarmoured and unmounted will not only secure us victory, it is the surest way to keep you alive.

dialogues.speaker: KNIGHT
dialogues.text: Rot.

dialogues.speaker: WESTMORLAND
dialogues.text: And I will say this: if our King were to ask you to sacrifice yourself, for the greater good of the realm, I’d expect you honour that request as any loyal and stouthearted subject should.  87.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal walks the camp in only the lightest of armour. Archer string bows, arrows are bundled. Horses sense looming dan and scuff hoofs in the dirt. Hal rounds a corner to find Falstaff outside the armoury being dressed in his heavy armour. Metal all over. He see

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: This wind whips from the north. (smiles) These are clouds sent from England.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Why are you being fitted? We were to fight without plate.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: We need a front line to draw them in.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: It can’t be you.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: The idea was mine. Some man must lead that first push to sell it well. Falstaff fastens his armour.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My men have been assembled. Most would rather wear the full suit. It gives comfort. And I can’t in all good conscience send them down there to realise my speculative drivel without getting muddy alongside them.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: I will fight with you.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF
dialogues.text: (smiles) Noble. You know it can’t be. The armourer lifts Falstaff’'s shoulder plate over his he  88.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hal. (corrects himself, smiles) My liege. This is what I was built for. I die here or I die over a bottle in Eastcheap. I think this makes for a better story. And you have things still to do. (beat) You will join the fight. Be sure not to join it early. Promise that. No matter what you see down there. We must first draw them all in. All of them. Falstaff rests his palm on Hal’s cheek.

dialogues.speaker: FALSTAFF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We win. It will be an honour. So win, my friend. And maybe then you'll lighten enough to have a drink with me. He grabs his helmet and waddles away. Hal watches him, lo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Light rain continues to fall. Hal strides between tents, distressed. His horse is tethered, attendants in wait. He checks and tightens its saddle. The Archbishop appears be him. An attendant holds an umbrella over the Archbishop.

dialogues.speaker: ARCHBISHOP
dialogues.text: Your Majesty, I have come to wish you well. I hope to offer a prayer for the men before you set off. Hal ignores him, mounts his horse and rides into the camp Men watch him pass, William among them, as he makes for t empty battlefield and then rides at speed, alone, across towards the French camp. All are dumbfounded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Commotion at the French camp at sight of Hal’s lone appro Hal arrives and dismounts. Frenchmen are armed and wary.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: (in French, subtitled) Where is the Dauphin?  89. EXT. DAUPHIN’S TENT / AGINCOURT - MORNING Hal on bended knee.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: (in French, subtitled) I humbly thank you for receiving me, noble lord. The Dauphin, smug on his throne, surrounded by his entour

dialogues.speaker: DAUPHIN
dialogues.text: Speak English. Please. I enjoy to speak English. It is simple and ugly. Hal stands, trying to hide his contempt.

dialogues.speaker: DAUPHIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I have been awaiting your surrender all the morning. All the night. It might have saved us all a great unease had you offered it sooner.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: I know you speak not for your father -

dialogues.speaker: DAUPHIN
dialogues.text: (haughtily) I do speak for him.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: I know you do not speak for your father and so I come now to you directly. I have not come to surrender. But too much Christian blood will be spilled on this field today, and so I propose that you and I fight one man on one man, we fight in our armies’ stead. If I lose, my men will leave this place forthwith and forever. If I win, I will assume this kingdom’s crown upon your father’s death. I know he is not long for this earth and so I will let him see done his days in peace. But once he is gone, France will be mine. The Dauphin doesn’t respond, then squirms and scoffs.

dialogues.speaker: HAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What say you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you afraid, young Henry?

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: What say you?

dialogues.speaker: DAUPHIN
dialogues.text: Are you afraid of this battle? There is no shame of it. The Dauphin’s posturing is hollow. Clearly, he doesn’t wa to fight Hal. Clearly, his men would rather he did.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Save your men.

dialogues.speaker: DAUPHIN
dialogues.text: (anger rising) Save your own men. Surrender to me. You have come here. To me.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: I can not do that.

dialogues.speaker: DAUPHIN
dialogues.text: Well, then, boy, let us make famous that field out there. Let us make famous this little village of Agincourt that will forever mark the site of your callow disgrace. Hal stares him down. He knows there is no deal to be done

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rain has intensified. Hal rides slowly back from the field and between rows of his ready men. Falstaff’s small armoured vanguard. Archers. Infantry. All wait. Thousands hardened, nervous men. All eerily silent. Hal surveys them. He searches their eyes, his distress visible. All is strangely quiet. Then -

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: You expect of me a speech? I have only one to give - and it is the same one I would were we not standing here on the brim of a battlefield. It’s the same one I'd give were we to meet by chance in the street. It is this: I have only ever hoped, I have only ever longed for one thing. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: HAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: To live to see our kingdom united. To see our kingdom united under this English crown. He dismounts and walks among the men, searching their fac He is on the verge of tears. The men watch him, uncertain

dialogues.speaker: HAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: All men are born to die. We know it. We carry it with us always. If your day is today, then so be it. Mine will be tomorrow. Or mine today and yours tomorrow. It matters not. What matters is that you know, in your hearts, that today you are that kingdom united. You are England. All of it. Each and every one of you. England is you. And it is the space between you. Fight not for yourselves, but for that space. Hal takes an arm each of the two men nearest him and plac it on the other’s shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: HAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fight for that space. Fill it. Make it tissue. Make it mass. He urges others to place their arms on others’ shoulders. gesture quickly spreads across the entire army.

dialogues.speaker: HAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Make it impenetrable. Make it unassailable. Make it yours. Hal’s emotions have spilled over. He lets the men see his vulnerability, his raw wound. They look back at him. They soak him in.

dialogues.speaker: HAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Make it England! Beat. And then, loud -

dialogues.speaker: HAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Captains to it. Lords and great men all. Each man to it. Falstaff smiles and puts on his helmet. His men follow su a formidable battalion of knights.  92.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Dauphin, decked in clean, flouncy armour, watches the English force cross the field. A COMMANDER is next to him

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER
dialogues.text: Les imbéciles. The commander strides away.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Attention! The Dauphin watches, almost smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Falstaff crosses the line of his men. He drags his sword their armour chest plates, a version of his own speech. He lowers his face guard, breathes, and then - his band o men begin their slow foot-march across the field. Hal stands with Westmorland. They watch, tense. He moves towards the flanking forest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Falstaff and his men march across the field. Their line i tight. They move slow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal strides through the forest flank, all the while watch Falstaff’s advance. He meets Dorset, who waits with hundr of other men - a team of guerilla fighters on the edge of forest. Maces and daggers and leather tunics at most. Everyone stripped down to bare minimum garb. The French still haven’t moved. Tension rises.  93.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Falstaff's retinue continues its march. The French mounte line on the hill before them still hasn’t moved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal watches the field. And then a horn blows, and the fir French cavalry line begins its descent down the hill - bu it’s only one line, moving slow.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Archers.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Archers! The archers call is relayed through the forest to -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - Westmorland who raises his hand.

dialogues.speaker: WESTMORLAND
dialogues.text: Archers! Thousands of English archers step forward and load their bows. They raise them to sky - and then release in unison

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A swarm of arrows rain down on the advancing French force already slipping on the wet ground. As the arrows hit wit deadly force, chaos erupts - horses bash into each other, French line splinters, knights fall from their mounts and trampled. Those horses still advancing break into a gallop towards marching line of Falstaff’s men. Falstaff’s men hold tight and then, as the mounted French disarray is almost upon them, they take to a knee, pole-a and swords braced into the ground. When the French line h these weapons are speared into the breasts and legs of ho that fall and thrash. French knights are thrown into the and all hell breaks loose. The battlefield quickly turns into a seething mess of mud flailing knights and confused thrashing horses. Men are trampled and bashed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A knight, fallen in the mud, gets stuck face down and cra around helplessly. He tries to lift himself. A horse fall top of him, pinning him to drown in the sodden earth. Falstaff is himself crawling on the ground, wrestling wit French knight. He holds the knight’s helmet in the mud, suffocating him, while himself being pummeled by men and horses. When the knight stops moving he tries desperately get back to his feet - near impossible with men and horse right on top of him. He manages to grab onto a horse’s stirrup and lift himsel up, only to find himself jammed between the rumps of two terrified horses. Desperate for breath, Falstaff manages get his helmet off. He lifts his face to the sky and suck the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal watches the carnage from the forest flank. He wants t fight, but knows he can’t until the rest of the French fo is drawn in. That force sits on top of the hill, unmoving

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Dauphin watches from his position as the fight unfold below. He signals to his commander.

dialogues.speaker: COMMANDER
dialogues.text: Avance! The Dauphin dons his menacing, elaborately decorated helm

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal watches as a horn blows and the rest of the French fo hundreds of armoured knights on foot - march down the hil Hal turns to Dorset.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: They come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Westmorland signals again.

dialogues.speaker: WESTMORLAND
dialogues.text: Archers!  95. The archers, loaded and ready, raise their bows to the sk and release another barrage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These arrows rain down on the second French line, sending into its own chaos. The battlefield is now like a swirling mosh-pit. Knights either on the ground being trampled or somehow still upri but without room to lift their arms let alone to swing a weapon in their heavy armour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal is poised.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Now. Call it.

dialogues.speaker: DORSET
dialogues.text: Men-at-arms!

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: On me! A horn is blown. And with that, from all sides, the strip down English infantry run like crazy looters from the forested flanks onto the field. Hal leads the charge. As men are cut down around him, he throws himself into th fray, confounding the French with speed and agility, just Falstaff had pictured. He slides and falls, but is nimbly back to his feet, dodging and moving, cutting and stabbin Armoured French knights fall and flail. Hal jams his dagg into their throats as he is sucked into the swirling pit. Hal is dragged to the ground by a floundering French knig He caves the knight’s helmet in with the hilt of his dagg and then crawls beneath a horse’s belly to get back to hi feet. He manages to suck in air. He looks to the sky as another barrage of English arrows flies overhead. All slows down as he surveys the field - and we are lead a slow-motion sequence of shots of the terrified horses o the battlefield. The RAIN begins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As we return to real time again, the rain is falling. Hal somehow lying on the flank of a dying horse. He is dragged off and thrown into the mud. While the grou is carpeted with dead and dying, the fighting is already beginning to thin. From the ground, Hal can see Westmorla being attacked by two French knights. As he’s about to be overcome, Hal steps in and hacks one them down, giving Westmorland the time and space to finis the other. Hal is sucked back into the morass - until eerily it clea Hal turns to see the Dauphin before him, high on his hors flanked by two equally menacingly armoured mounted guards A space clears on the thinning field, as the Dauphin dismounts and approaches Hal. Hal picks up a discarded sword and readies himself.

dialogues.speaker: DAUPHIN
dialogues.text: Come then, King of England. Hal approaches him slowly and venomously. The Dauphin charges - and then immediately slips over in mud. He flounders. Tries to stand, slips again. Hal watches him - as do all the other men on the field - exhausted, sucking in air, battle-scarred. Hal looks to the Dauphin’s guards atop their horses. They offer no assistance. They sit motionless atop their horses looking down on their squirming leader. Hal steps back and nods to a group of his own men - who charge at the Dauphin, tackling him to the ground and tea into him with their daggers. Hal walks away as the sound of HORNS echoes across the fi and his tired army breaks into a victory roar. Hal forges a path through the mud and gore, scouring the ground, searching faces of the dead and dying while rider horses roam the field too - as if on their own search.  97. He searches more urgently until he stops over another cor He drops to his knees, then sits in the mud beside the bo Falstaff - lifeless and serene. Hal sits with him and cries. He looks out at the battlefi watching the celebration of his men. He then rests his he on Falstaff’s back. He sits this way a long moment. Finally, Hal looks up. He sees a mass of his fellow soldi spread across the field, watching him. Some two hundred m Then - the closest soldier kneels. Followed by a second. Hal is soon faced with an entire army kneeling before him He stands and walks slowly across the field as more take the position. Westmorland approaches, filthy, exhausted. He bows.

dialogues.speaker: WESTMORLAND
dialogues.text: My liege. He stands and smiles. They hug, but Hal’s is without joy. WESTMORLAND (CONT’D) The prisoners we have took are a rabble. I fear we will not secure them should their army regroup. Hal looks at him, strangely distant.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Kill them all. Hal walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The English army marches in slow silent procession along trail towards the town of Nancy. Hal, on horseback, leads the procession. William and Dors beside him. The Archbishop is there too, smugly proud. A thin crowd of peasant villagers lines the trail. The atmosphere is strange, cold and muted. The people have co out to see the invaders, their conquerors.  98.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the courtyard of impressive civic buildings, Hal dismounts. French officials are there to greet him. The FRENCH LORD STEWARD genuflects. The air is tense.

dialogues.speaker: FRENCH LORD STEWARD
dialogues.text: (in French, subtitled) Your Highness. His Majesty King Charles is here to meet you. (beat) He is sunning himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal is lead onto a colonnaded stone porch.

dialogues.speaker: FRENCH LORD STEWARD
dialogues.text: (in French, subtitled) Your Majesty, King Henry the Fifth of England. Across the porch, an old man in regal attire sits ina reclined chair. He is barefoot. He speaks English.

dialogues.speaker: KING CHARLES VI
dialogues.text: Your Highness. Welcome. Please, come sit here with me. Hal crosses the porch. Charles gestures for him to sit. KING CHARLES VI (CONT’D) Please. Hal sits. William, the Archbishop and others remain stand KING CHARLES VI (CONT’D) I like to have the sun on my skin. But not too much. Too much is very dangerous. So I take only a small amount. Among Charles's entourage, seated discreetly in the setti is a young woman, 20 - the only woman in the room. KING CHARLES VI (CONT’D) And here I meet the man about whom I have heard such a great deal. Much of it apocryphal, no doubt. Rumour and gossip. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KING CHARLES VI (CONT’D) And yet when finally you are here before me, this apocrypha becomes air. Or memory. Nothing. He searches Hal’s eyes. Hal seems calm and quietly contai KING CHARLES VI (CONT’D) I can only imagine the stories that have been told about me. And about my own son. No doubt you have heard many. I suspect they may be the reason we are here today. My son was impetuous. And what he felt, he felt keenly - for better or for worse. Very often for worse. And the best defence I can summon now is that he was young. Maybe it is a poor defence. But I hope it is one with which you might feel some affinity. I hope also that you might understand my need to grieve his death as all fathers must grieve their lost sons - whatever their failings.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: I do understand.

dialogues.speaker: KING CHARLES VI
dialogues.text: Thank you. Charles pauses, thinking. KING CHARLES VI (CONT’D) This conversation we have - or are about to have - has been had many times before and will be had many times again for centuries to come, between men from all corners, between men of vanity and men of good reason, in whatever combination. I would like to believe that you and I are men of good reason. Men of vanity would have this trouble continue until the brink of our mutual devastation. Maybe beyond. Charles looks around at Hal’s entourage, gently assaying men for the first time. KING CHARLES VI (CONT’D) I have, of course, travelled here to offer you my surrender.  100. The Archbishop smiles proudly. KING CHARLES VI (CONT’D) Maybe it is our shared destiny that our lands be ruled as one. We have shared histories - shared apocrypha. Might it be that this is the path we have travelled to make our unity so. Hal looks at the old man. His equanimity is humbling.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Do you ask anything of me in return?

dialogues.speaker: KING CHARLES VI
dialogues.text: No. Charles searches Hal’s eyes, then shifts his gaze to the woman sitting nearby. She lowers her eyes. KING CHARLES VI (CONT’D) I do, however, have for you a proposition - that as a gesture of harmony and goodwill you take the hand of my daughter, Catherine, in marriage. Hal looks to PRINCESS CATHERINE, who looks back at him, defiant. KING CHARLES VI (CONT’D) My son caused me much pain. And by extension he caused more pain to both of us than I care to examine. But my daughter... She would follow me to the far corners without dispute. I would hope that a bond between you, between us, might prevent these troubles from recurring. Charles looks to Catherine. Hal looks to her also. KING CHARLES VI (CONT’D) It is most uncanny, and yet not so at all, that the great movements of history so frequently find their origins in the minutia of family. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KING CHARLES VI (CONT’D) That in ways I dare not unsettle here I must only assume that my relationship with my son, and yours with your father - these are the things that have led us here today. We are leaders of lands and of peoples and yet it is family that moves us. Family consumes us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal sits alone at the ship’s bow. He looks out to sea, at fleet returning home. The weather is clear and calm. All strangely quiet. William approaches.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: My liege. He takes a seat beside Hal.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How do you feel?

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Tired.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: My condolences to you for the loss of Sir John. I know you must feel this loss deeply.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Thank you, William. Your loyalty to me has been comforting.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: It is my honour and duty, my liege.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: It would seem comfort is a valuable commodity to a man in my position.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: You have proved yourself a most worthy king. I should say that already you have proven yourself to be one of England's great kings. Hal nods. A tired smile. He looks out to sea. He is a vic warrior and king.  102. INT. KING’S BEDCHAMBER / ROYAL COURT - DAY Hal is dressed in finery. He stands alone at the window, listening to a huge crowd outside. The Lord Chamberlain enters.

dialogues.speaker: LORD CHAMBERLAIN
dialogues.text: My liege. A crowd has gathered.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: So I see.

dialogues.speaker: LORD CHAMBERLAIN
dialogues.text: Shall I escort you to the east wing?

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: No. I will be ready shortly.

dialogues.speaker: LORD CHAMBERLAIN
dialogues.text: As you wish, Your Majesty. The Lord Chamberlain exits. Hal stands thinking a moment longer. He seems calm. He turns and heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal walks the hall. Aides bow as he passes unexpectedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Princess Catherine is attended by ladies-in-waiting. Ther a KNOCK at the door.

dialogues.speaker: LADY-IN-WAITING
dialogues.text: Enter. Hal enters. He closes the door behind him and bows.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: (to her aides) Veuillez nous laisser. The aides file out of the room. Catherine is seated.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (in French, subtitled) Please sit, Your Majesty. Hal approaches hesitantly and sits opposite Catherine.  Beat. 103.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: (in French, subtitled) You are beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: Merci.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: (in French, subtitled) I will no longer speak French. We must speak English.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: (in French, subtitled) I cannot speak English.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: (in French, subtitled) You will learn.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: (in French, subtitled) I wonder, then, how our union might proceed in the meantime.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: There is much I wonder about a great many things.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: (in English) Indeed there must be for you to contemplate marriage to a woman about whom you know so little. Hal is caught off guard. She watches him a moment.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I will not submit to you. You must earn my respect. I am not my father. My father is old and tired and he no longer has the will to fight. But I am young and I have that will in abundance. This is the woman you have chosen to take as your wife. Hal looks at her, still befuddled.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: I understand that.  104.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: Do you?

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: Do you feel a sense of achievement?

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: In what regard?

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: In any regard. Hal looks at her. He wasn’t expecting to be challenged.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: I have achieved that which my father never could. I have united this kingdom in common cause.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: You have achieved momentary respite. A unity forged under false pretense will never be a unity that prevails. Hal is taken aback, but engaged by Catherine.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: How, pray, have my endeavours been forged falsely?

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: Why did you bring war to France?

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Your father came on spoiling.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: How so? How was he spoiling?

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: He sent an assassin.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: There was no assassin. There was no plot to kill you.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: And how might you be sure?  105.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: Because I was with my father when he received word of your charge. I know him well enough to know his reaction to be genuine.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: How was his reaction?

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: He laughed. He laughed very much. He said you must be drunk.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Your father is a madman.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: He may be mad, but he is true. His madness makes him true. He says only what he believes. That is why he is loved. Hal's demeanour starts to shift, darken.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: The assassin then was sent by your brother.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: My brother? My brother was too stupid to conjure such a plan. For all of his failings, he was not one to send a killer in his stead. He preferred to do his killing himself. What was your true reason?

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Did you know of the ball he sent? The ball that he sent to me?

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: He sent to you a ball? Beat. She lets this hang. Hal shifts uncomfortably.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He sent to you a ball... Is that why you have -

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Why should you question my intent? Your father’s rule is illegitimate. He has no right claim to his -  106.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: All monarchy is illegitimate. You yourself are the son of a usurper. Hal sits, thinking, darkening.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It would seem that you have no explanation for what you have done. You have shed the blood of so many Christian souls and yet before me now I see only a young and vain and foolish man, so easily riled and so easily beguiled. Hal is staring at her now. His thoughts are splintering.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Have you contemplated this? Have you contemplated the ambitions of the men around you? Still no response from Hal. Hal and Catherine stare at each other. She isn’t sure how will react - she expects opprobrium. She knows she has sp provocatively. Instead Hal responds with unsettling calm.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: I must leave you now. He stands and bows. She nods cautiously. Hal exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal walks the hall briskly, his head swimming. More nervo genuflection from aides caught off guard by his passing. He rounds a corner, down a hall, his eyes fixed and cold. reaches a door. He opens it without pausing or knocking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal enters. William is standing on a little stool, having gaudy ceremonial robes lint-brushed by a pageboy.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (sprightly) My liege. Hal closes the door behind him. He sits in a chair by the door and watches William who looks at himself in a mirror  107.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You must be sure to revel in this day. A crowd gathered to honour victory. These are the rare moments for which a king lives. Beat. Hal tries to still his swirling thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: In all my preoccupation, I have neglected to ask after your family.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Your preoccupations are hardly trifling, my liege.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: You have two sons.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: And your wife minds your estate in your absence.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: She does. Yes.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Yours is sheep. You’re a man of wool.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I am. As my father was before me.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: How many head?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Some four thousand at last count. Mostly Dorset horns.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: How much land have you?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: To be true, I’m not wholly certain. Many hundreds of beautiful acres.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: What lands in France have you now annexed? A pause. William looking at himself in the mirror.  108.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I’m not sure I understand, my liege.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Now that France is ours, how much of her land is now yours?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: My liege?

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Her farming land, her sheep grazing land. How much of it is now yours? William is troubled by the course Hal’s enquiry has taken

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: This has yet to be determined. Our conquest is so recent. Why do you ask, my liege? Hal watches William, contempt brewing.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My liege? William moves to step down off his little stool.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Don’t move. Stay up there. Hal stares at him. William steps back onto his little sto The pageboy can clearly sense the tension. He sits back, the floor, and tries to make himself invisible.

dialogues.speaker: HAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: How did my assassin come to you?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (flustered) I am afraid I do not understand your meaning.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: My question is simple. You brought the assassin to my attention. Under what circumstances did he come to yours?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I, I fail to remember at this moment.  109.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Remedy this failure.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I, ah, let me recall... So much has happened in the intervening months.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: An event so pivotal should be amply equipped to penetrate the fog of time elapsed.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Yes, of course. Let me recall...

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Was it in the street? Did he come to you in the street?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes, he did. He approached me in the street, most unusually. My liege, please tell me the cause of this concern. William moves again to step off his little stool.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Stay up there. William shuffles awkwardly back on to the stool.

dialogues.speaker: HAL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He came to you in the street. Did he know your name?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I, ah, I do not believe he did.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: How then did he know who you were to approach?

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: I, ah, I’m not certain. Perchance... But, no, give me pause - the memory is returning. Of course. He surrendered himself to a palace guard and the matter was brought to my attention and I was then taken to him in his cell.  110.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: So he did not meet you in the street.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: No. It was not in the street. Forgive me. I was summoned to the cells to interrogate the wretch. He had already surrendered himself. Hal stares at him. William squirms.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: My liege, please. Has a problem arisen?

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Yes. A problem has arisen. And it wobbles before me now on its silly little stool at mine own elevation.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: My liege. I don’t understand.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: Stop this charade now.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: Sincerely, I don’t -

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: (yelling)

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM
dialogues.text: (explodes ) I have given you what you wanted, boy! Have I not?! William and Hal breathe, shocked at their own respective outbursts. Everything has changed. William steps off his stool and goes the window.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You wanted peace. This is how peace is forged. It is forged in victory. The crowd noise outside swells. William points to the win

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Listen. Do you hear it? He and Hal listen to the crowd.  111.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That is the sound of peace. Hal watches him then drops his head. William steps gently toward him.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That is the sound of peace. Hal looks up, defeated, lonely. William extends his arms.

dialogues.speaker: WILLIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That is the sound of your greatness. William takes Hal’s head gently in his hands. Hal lets himself be mollified. William smiles. William lowers himself and genuflects. He bows with rever and rests his forehead on Hal’s knee. Hal lets it sit there a moment, and then - he takes the e of the scarf draped across William’s shoulders and pulls tight around William’s throat. William struggles immediately. He writhes and kicks as Ha chokes him. Hal’s grip is deathly strong. His eyes glaze with venom. William thrashes, Hal stares coldly ahead, at the pageboy kneeling motionless and staring at the floor. William takes a long time to die. Eventually his writhing slows. And then stops. Hal drops him like a sack to the floor. Hal breathes. He stands and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hal enters the office which is now full of courtiers - am them Dorset and Westmorland. The crowd outside is loud. As Hal enters, all present bow. He stands and surveys the room. He surveys the people in it, genuflecting before hi Catherine is there. He goes to her. She watches his appro She can see that something has shifted in him.  112. Hal holds his hand out to her. She takes it cautiously.

dialogues.speaker: HAL
dialogues.text: (quiet, only for her) I ask nothing of you other than that you will always speak to me clear and true. Always. Will you promise me only that? She looks at him, gently searching his face.

dialogues.speaker: CATHERINE
dialogues.text: I will. He leads her to the balcony. As they step out, into the blinding light, the crowd roar
